resources.string: No, fool!
We shall meet again!
Victory is mine!
I suggest you hear me out.
Wretched creature! Do you think to defy me?
Attack! Kill them all!
I'll swallow your soul!
May the hells take you!
Steady now... This is going to hurt...
I'm hurt? Quickly now... Fix this!
Don't make me call you again... Assist me!
Well... What have we here?
Yes.
No.
Next time, I won't be so pleasant.
Oh, you can bet I have something to say about that...
You'll beg for death before I'm through...
Lay them low! Attack!
Mess with me, will you?
That's it - you're dead!
Time to put a hurt on.
I could use some patching up.
I need help! Now!
This looks like trouble.
It's too much! Get out of here!
Why don't you save us both some time and start begging now.
I need you by my side!
Stop here for a moment.
Ohh, damn..
It's poison... damn.
Hey, wha... you distracted me!
Okay, this is not going to work.
This way.
What's this?
Fall in here!
One side, one side!
I need this open.
Look around.
Shh. We need to be quiet.
Got it, no problem.
Can't do it, chief.
All done.
Ooof, my knees are buckling!
Mmmm?
Greetings!
Yep.
Nah.
Stop!
Okay, we all need rest now.
We. Are. Wasting. Time.
Travel well.
Thanks.
Sweet merciful crap!
Alright!
Hey!
Yeah, sounds good.
No - won't work.
When I'm done even the buzzards won't want you.
Please subdue them, if you would be so kind.
You'll wish you hadn't!
Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear.
If that's the way you want it, then.
If you would be so kind as to heal me...
Help, help!
Looks like bad folk ahead.
I'm afraid we must be leaving.
Not the sharpest of swords, are you?
Please guard me. Much thanks
Hold for a second, please.
Death approaches me.
I have been poisoned.
Humph, not used to that happening.
Doesn't look like this will work.
This way, please.
Hmm, how interesting.
If you could all come over here, please.
Pardon..
Could you be so good as to open this?
Now let's all look around us.
Quiet, eveyone.
But of course.
Sadly, I cannot.
All done.
This is more than I can bear.
Mmmhmm?
Hello there.
Yes
No.
Don't move!
We should rest now.
This is unproductive. Let us move on.
Fare well to you.
Why, thank you!
Oh, fiddlesticks!
How exciting!
If I may...
Very astute!
Um, no.
You would do well to leave. Now.
Trust in Mystra and bring them down!
My art will bring you low.
You will rue the day you invited my attack!
Prepare to face the judgement of Mystra!
Mystra, send your healing power to me!
Help! Help!
There they are! We'll easily destroy them.
Oh goddess! We're all going to die!
I don't believe that you are worth my time.
Quick, hurry, protect me!
Stop and wait right there.
Mmph!
Unnh!
Ah!
Mystra, take them, not me!
Oh no! Quick, I need an antidote! Help!
What? What just happened -- that's inconceivable!
Well, this is what happens when you don't use magic.
Oh, for heavens' sake, follow me.
Pay attention!
Everyone gather around me.
Stand aside, peasant.
This mechanical device doesn't merit the energy of a knock spell. One of you deal with it.
Don't just stand there, look around more carefully.
Do I have to waste an invisibility spell, or do you think you can manage to stay hidden?
Of course I can do that!
That's not worth my time.
It's done.
This is too much weight! Aren't there hirelings to carry these things for us?
Yes?
Yes, hello.
Yes, of course.
No, certainly not.
Stop!
Isn't this enough for one day? I need to refresh my spells.
Well, this is special.
Oh, goodbye.
Thank you for giving that into my keeping.
Shar take you!
By my art, we have triumphed!
Stop and listen to me.
That's a splendid idea.
I hardly think that's wise.
Don't force me to use my powers against you.
For the glory of Mystra, attack! Smite them down! Destroy the evil ones! Strike-- hey, wait for me!
In Mystra's name!
Have at you!
Mystra grant me strength!
In the Lady's name, I beg you for healing.
Mystra, let help come to my side now!
Look! Evil creatures to smite! Let's go attack!
Let us press onward and die in glorious battle!
Dare you face me, evil creature? I bet you don't!
Guard me as we fight, and I shall do the same for you!
Hold your ground!
I can feel Mystra's arms reaching out to embrace me...
Oh, ugh! Poison creeping through my veins!
Mystra must not have wanted that to work.
My sword may have failed me, but my faith remains strong!
Come, follow me!
Look over here, quickly!
All of us should come together at once.
Please move over, won't you?
Hmm, this won't open. Does anyone have a knock spell?
I don't see anything around, but maybe you might!
Even though this seems to call for stealth, I think we should charge ahead!
Of course I can do that!
Of course I can do that! Well, actually, I can't. I'm sorry.
I'm finished!
Ouch, this is as heavy as I imagine the weight of a guilty conscience would be.
Yes?
Hello!
Yes, of course!
No.
Let's stop for a moment.
Can we stop for a while? I need to perform my devotions.
Surely there's some evil out there we could be smiting...
Mystra keep you!
May Mystra bless you for your kindness!
May Mystra condemn it to the bleakest hell!
For the glory of Mystra!
Wait, I have something to say to you.
Yes, that's a splendid idea!
Yes, that's a wonderful idea... I think.
Don't make me come over there and hurt you.
For Jotunheim!
You can expect no mercy!
Your death will be glorious.
Gods preserve me, I need healing!
Quickly now, aid me!
Why do you disturb me?
Yes.
No.
You can see yourself out.
Victory is mine!
You had better believe I have something to say about that.
You cannot hope to defeat me.
Let slip the dogs of war! Well get to it, dogs!
Taste true power!
My magic will make short work of you!
I will destroy you.
I need healing. Now.
A little help would be appreciated!
Looks like trouble. Excellent.
You can't possibly win. I'm leaving.
Is that your face or has your neck thrown up?
Protect me, would you? Thanks.
Hold it!
Look what your incompetence has led to!
Poisoned. Great.

Quit Neverwinter Nights?
What!?! How is that even possible?
Well this clearly won't work.

Ki Strike +3
This is not a school, but instead represents the wizard's desire to have an equal understanding of all spells, without focusing on a single school of magic. Prohibited School: None
Abjuration spells are used to shield the caster from magical and physical attacks. Prohibited School: Conjuration
A conjuration specialist can bring creatures to him, usually in the form of summoned allies. Prohibited School: Transmutation

Diviners are capable of looking forward in time to anticipate what will happen next. Although mostly useful for gathering information, several divine spells help the caster in combat situations. Prohibited School: Illusion
Enchantment spells involving gaining control over another creature, or imbuing a recipient with special properties. Prohibited School: Illusion
Evocation spells manipulate energy or create something from nothing. Many of the best offensive spells can be found within this school of magic. Prohibited School: Conjuration
Illusion spells alter perception to create images of unreal things, or to disguise real things. Prohibited School: Enchantment
Necromancy spells manipulate, create, or destroy life. Prohibited School: Divination
Transmutation spells transform the recipient or his environment, either subtly or obviously. Prohibited School: Conjuration

The Neverwinter Nights Configuration Utility has detected that this computer is running Windows XP.
The default video drivers installed with Windows XP do not include OpenGL support, which is required to run Neverwinter Nights. Please ensure that the installed video drivers support OpenGL. Contact your video card manufacturer for information on how to obtain and install adequate drivers before trying to run Neverwinter Nights or the BioWare Aurora Neverwinter Nights Toolset.
To test OpenGL compatibility, the Neverwinter Nights Configuration Utility will now perform several tests. These tests may fail and cause the program to crash if the installed video drivers do not support OpenGL.
Would you like to skip with the OpenGL tests?
Press "No" to proceed with the tests if the installed video drivers support OpenGL. Press "Yes" to skip the OpenGL tests. If there is any doubt whether the system includes adequate OpenGL support, please press "Yes".

I doubt you will find any other axeman for hire who is my equal. You have a noble and honorable bearing, so I will reduce my normal fee. Only 150 gold pieces and I am your willing servant.

Greetings, <sir/madam>. I see you are not yet infected by the plague that ravages Neverwinter. Among such suffering and misery we who are not yet afflicted must be grateful for our health.
You will not regret this, my <lord/lady>. My skills are yours to command.
I doubt you will find any other axeman for hire who is my equal. Only 200 gold pieces and I am your willing servant.

If you feel that is best. What would you like to change?
How far away do you want me to stay?

Very well, I shall stay a reasonably far distance away from you whenever possible.

Very well, I will search whenever we are moving.

Very well, I will no longer attempt to open locked doors or chests.
That is unfortunate, but I must earn a living through my skills. I cannot work for free. Is there something else you need?
I see you have returned, <sir/madam>. What brings you back to the Trade of Blades?
Greetings and well met. You are <FullName>, aren't you? The one responsible for saving the city of Neverwinter. Your deeds have become something of a legend.
Greetings once more, <sir/madam>. It is I, Daelan Red Tiger, warrior of the Uthgardt Red Tiger tribe. Remember?
<FirstName>! It is a pleasure to see you again, though not altogether unexpected. I had heard that Aribeth recruited you to stamp out the foul cult that was responsible for the plague.
I bid you welcome, <FullName>. I have heard many tales of your exploits in Neverwinter and Luskan. You are truly a <man/woman> of great honor.
Greetings and well met, <FirstName>. It is good to look upon you once more. No doubt Aarin Gend has brought you here to aid in the search for the Words of Power.
I bid you welcome once more, <FirstName>. Have you need of a skilled warrior? I am eager to join in the search for the Words of Power.
I have been waiting for you - I suspected you would return. Do you need me to join with you once more?
I serve another another master now. I have nothing further to say to you.
I found passing from this world unsettling - as was my return to life. Yet I sense there has been no permanent harm done. Do you need me to join you once more, <FirstName>?
I am not one to boast of my own abilities, yet the skill and ferocity of the Uthgardt tribes are well known throughout the North.
IGNORE THIS STARTING CONDITION. THIS IS USED AS A TRASH FOR UNWANTED LINKS. DO NOT DELETE THESE LINKS.
As you wish, <sir/madam>. Come back if you ever wish to hire a warrior of great skill and honor.
I am Daelan Red Tiger of the Uthgardt tribes of the frozen North. But it has been over a year since I left my people and came to Neverwinter. Now I earn my living as a blade for hire.
With my friends dead there was no reason to stay in the docks. Not with things getting... worse. Now I earn a living with my axe as a freelance mercenary.
I am no stranger to battle or bloodshed, but I am a warrior with honor. I will not undertake any sinister mission. Had I desired such work I could have found employment back at the docks.
Aribeth's reputation is well known throughout the city, so I have no fear your mission will bring dishonor to me. I will work for you, if we can agree upon a fair price for my services.
I can understand that. If you are working for Aribeth then I am certain your 'mission' must be of great importance.

The quarantine trapped ships in port, swelling the number of pirates and other criminals in the district - men with no honor. And with the city guard focused on the plague, these evil men have seized control of the docks.

Before I left I heard talk in the district of an auction to be held at Jim Seedy's tavern. Something besides the usual stolen merchandise, illegal goods and helpless slaves sold at his filthy den of sin.
There is little else I can tell you about the docks, but I know the district is dangerous. If you intend to go there you would be wise to take along a hired blade.
I do have some knowledge of the docks district, as I worked there before the plague. It was a dangerous and sinister place when I left... though I suspect things have only grown worse since then.
Your are modest to share the praise, though it does nothing to diminish the honor you have rightly earned.

I am Daelan Red Tiger, a noble warrior from the Uthgardt tribes of the north. No doubt your mission here is the same as mine: to aid Aribeth in stamping out the cult that was responsible for the Wailing Death.
Ummm... yes I already know that you work for Aribeth. By the way, you are... drooling.
If you find yourself in need of a strong warrior to aid you, come back and speak to me. My blade is ready to aid you in this mission.
It seems Lord Nasher is determined to root out the cult that brought so much suffering to his city. He has ordered all the mercenaries in Neverwinter to come to Port Llast to join in the search.
I answered the call without hesitation. I lost many friends to the plague and I am eager to avenge their deaths. The cowards who unleashed this curse must be made to pay.
I would accomplish little by dashing off on my own. My orders were to come here and help any who might need my blade.
Your reputation is well known, <FirstName>. I am no great hero such as you, but I am a skilled warrior of the Red Tiger tribe.
My people are well known for their bravery, honor, and ferocity in battle. I could be of great service to you in seeking out this cult, if you would have me.
I have heard nothing of the cult, though many suspect - as I do - that answers might be found in the city of Luskan.
That city has long been an enemy of Neverwinter. An evil blight upon the north, it is widely acknowledged as the home of murders and thieves - a place with no honor!
It would not surprisie me to discover links to the cult in that breeding den of evil, though I admit there is no evidence pointing to Luskan.
Of course I will bow to your lead, <FirstName>. I am honored to join my blade to the cause of such a great hero.
I will follow you and carry out your orders to the best of my abilities. If you wish to issue new orders, simply speak to me again.
My abilities have improved from practice. Give me a few seconds to rest and I'll be ready to show you what I've learned.
My strength is in weapons not words, <FirstName>.
As you wish. We should probably continue with your mission in any case.
I would ask, <FirstName>, that before I tell you about myself you tell me something of yourself. Among my people it is said that in knowing our companions we come to know ourselves.
I admit that I fight only for gold, but I know nothing of your motivations. Why do you serve Neverwinter during these darkest of times?
You are an honorable <man/woman>, <FirstName>. I too seek honor here in Neverwinter, though of a different sort.
So you seek to make a name for yourself here, <FirstName>? A noble cause, and one I am familiar with.
It would seem we are both nothing but ruthless mercenaries. Yet even in serving for gold we may perform great deeds of honor.
I came to this city to make a name for myself, <FirstName> - to forge a legend that even the tribe of my mother would hear. Instead I found myself guarding crates and barrels against common thugs.

Yet even in the sordid world of the docks my reputation spread. Several captains asked me to join their crews. Perhaps if the plague had not come the name Daelan Red Tiger would have become a legend on the high seas.
Perhaps it is for the best. Had I joined a ship's crew it is unlikely the Uthgardt would ever have heard of my accomplishments. My place is here, in the North.
This is the land of my birth, and this is where I must fulfill my destiny. I will bring no honor to my mother's name by fleeing on a ship!
Only if I stay can I hope to redeem the shame of my father's blood and end my exile!
In the time we have been together you have respected my request for privacy, <FirstName>. Now I feel I am ready to tell you the rest of my tale.
*Sigh* I suppose you deserve to know the rest of the story, <FirstName>. I have kept this weight upon my heart, but we are in this together.
I know I shall probably never find my mother's brooch again, <FirstName>, but I shall not give up hope. Without it my vision quest will never be revealed to me.
Please, <FirstName>, the things I said before... the words were... this is not the time to speak of such things. Perhaps later I will speak more of this. But not now.
There are no great secrets about me, <FirstName>; I am what I am. My father was an orc and my mother was an Uthgardt of the Red Tiger tribe.
Some in the cities fear us. They call us bloodthirsty savages, but they are ignorant of our ways. We are fierce warriors of great courage and honor, even if they do not understand.
I will not lie - I was never allowed to forget about my father's tainted orc blood. Yet if the tribe did not embrace me, at least they tolerated me.
Like the other young boys of our tribe I ran and climbed and swam and grew strong. I learned to hunt and fish. I learned the lore of our tribe. And most importantly I learned the honor of a warrior.
With my mother's death the time came for me to prove myself worthy of the tribe. I left in search of glory and honor in the outside world, to prove my spirit was true. I went to Luskan.
I suppose I owe you an explanation of my days in Luskan, <FirstName>, after all we have been through together.
You have been a true friend to me, <FirstName>. I have been reluctant to speak to you of this, but you did help me recover my mother's brooch. Perhaps you can help me with this as well.
I will not abandon the search for the cultists behind the plague; I have pledged my blade to you and it is yours as long as you need me.
This is not the time to speak of such things, <FirstName>. We must focus on rooting out the cult responsible for the Wailing Death. Perhaps we can speak of this later... when the time is right.
There are some who claim Aribeth betrayed Neverwinter out of grief, others say she seeks to avenge Fenthick's death out of some perverse sense of justice.
Neverwinter turned its back on her, the city rejected her and its people cast her out. There is no pain so great as being turned away by those you most want to take you in.
Perhaps not, but Aribeth no doubt felt that they did. The people blamed Fenthick enough to kill him, how could she not feel they despised her as well?

No doubt he thought it best to calm the people and keep Aribeth from suffering their wrath as Fenthick had. But in her grief she would have seen it as a cold and brutal rejection - a symbolic banishment.
We should focus on finding the Words of Power for Aarin Gend. But I suppose I could spare some time to share with you the legend of my people I mentioned earlier.
I promised to tell you the rest of the tale of Uthgar's Spear when the time was right, <FirstName>. That time has now come.
Do not fear, <FirstName>. As long as you seek the Words of Power my blade shall serve you. And in serving you, perhaps I will find Uthgar's Spear.
Perhaps later I will tell you the tale, but now is not the time for me to speak of this. We must focus on finding the Words of Power for Aarin Gend if we are to save Neverwinter.
Forgive me, <FirstName>, but I... I cannot speak of this anymore. It is too... painful.
Among my people there is nothing we value more than friendship. You have proved yourself a true friend, <FirstName>, so I give you this amulet as a sign of the bond we share.
Yes! Yes, that is the blood-soaked blade that has haunted my dreams! Then... the one who wields it is dead?
I can never properly repay you for this gift, <FirstName>, but please take this small token of my gratitude. It was a gift from my mother before she died.

That was partly the reason I stayed so long at the docks, hoping I might somehow discover the brooch. I am certain it is somewhere in the docks district, even now - if it was not burned on the bonfires of the plague corpses.
'Go', he said with his dying breath. I could do nothing more for him, so I fled before my actions were discovered. I left Luskan that night, a man saved from himself by another's sacrifice.
There is a lesson in the fall of the Uthgardt, a lesson Neverwinter would do well to heed. There is hope for the city yet, just as there is hope for the Uthgardt.
This is how I must prove myself worthy of my tribe, <FirstName>. I must find Uthgar's spear - though I do not know where to look.
I am grateful for all you have done for me, <FirstName>, but I did not follow you here. Make no mistake, Daelan Red Tiger is his own man.
I know we went our separate ways, <FirstName>, but it seems the gods have seen fit to bring us together once more.
It seems Lord Nasher is determined to root out the cult that brought so much suffering to his city. He has ordered all the mercenaries in Neverwinter to come to Port Llast to join in the search.
When Aribeth recruited the mercenaries we were all paid in advance for our services - well paid. Lord Nasher is sparing no expense in tracking down these cultists.
Farewell, <sir/madam>. My blade is at your service if you require the aid of a skilled and honorable warrior.
Then I shall bid you farewell. If you ever find yourself in need of a skilled and honorable warrior come speak to me again.
I would be honored to join my blade to your cause.
I have heard nothing of the cult, though many suspect - as I do - that answers might be found in the city of Luskan.
From what I have heard, your deeds go far beyond the scope of mere duty. I only hope my own fame is one day as widely spread as yours, <FullName>.
Farewell. If you find yourself in need of a courageous warrior, come speak to me again.
Yes, he has hired on dozens of mercenaries to aid him in this cause. We are to scour the North for the Words of Power, before they fall into the enemy's hands.
Though I am an Uthgardt warrior, born in the wild, I have lived in Neverwinter for nearly a year and the city is dear to my heart. I will do everything within my power to defend her walls.
I have heard nothing of these Words, though recent events concerning the Uthgardt Elk tribe might be worth investigating.
Though a capable warrior, I fear I would have little success on my own, <FirstName>. However, I would be honored to join my blade to your cause, if you would have me.
I will follow you and perform to the best of my abilities, according to the orders you have given me. Any time you wish to issue new orders you have only to speak to me again.
Then I bid you farewell. If you change your mind, come speak to me again.
After Aribeth's betrayal I meant to travel the north in search of the quest to prove myself to my tribe. Yet even as we parted ways I suspected we would meet once more, <FirstName>.
I find your anger inexplicable, <FirstName>. I come from a proud people and I will not subject myself to such abuse. Perhaps we can speak again when you are in a better mood.

And then I heard of Aarin Gend's call for all those who would serve the cause of Neverwinter to join the Lords' Alliance here at Beorunna's Well - a holy place to the Uthgardt. I thought it might be a sign from my gods.
After all you have done for Neverwinter I knew you would be here, <FirstName>. That is why I came, to join with you once more. I feel our fates are bound together.
Then once more my blade is yours to command, <FirstName>.
As you wish, <FirstName>. If you change your mind you can find me here.
I have heard nothing of these Words, though recent events concerning the Uthgardt Elk tribe might be worth investigating.
My blade is yours to command.
If you change your mind you can find me here.
My blade is yours to command.
If you change your mind you can find me here.
My tribe is noble, but small. Among them there was little chance for a young warrior to prove himself or earn a wife.
But I am young and strong and my people are renowned for their skill in battle. Here in Neverwinter I found work on the docks as a guard for the cargo and shipments being transported.
There are some in the city who call my people savages and barbarians, but they know nothing of the Uthgardt. We are great warriors and hunters, following the herds and living off the land.
The coming of the plague changed everything. The quarantine halted all incoming or outgoing ships. There was no work and no money. I should have left the docks then.
Many of the dock workers were afflicted - men I had come to know as friends. I stayed to ease their suffering, but in the end I could do nothing to save them from the Wailing Death.
The word spread quickly on the street. Perhaps I could have learned more before I left, but I had no interest in such transactions. I am a warrior, not a smuggler.
My father was an orc, and the blood of his inhuman race is in my veins. But I was raised by my mother among the tribes of the Uthgardt.
There is little I can tell you about the city. Since the plague I have spent most of my days here seeking employment.
An Uthgardt warrior knows no fear, but I will not dishonor my tribe. I refuse to serve these men! I will not become a common thug or murderer!
Please forgive me, <FirstName>. I became... lost in the moment. The drums of glory momentarily distracted me from the task at hand. It will not happen again.
As you command, <Sir/Madam>.
I... I mentioned my exile to you before, <FirstName>. The truth is, I did not willingly leave the Uthgardt to come to Neverwinter. The tribe cast me out.

I am a monstrous half-breed. As a child it was obvious my blood was tainted: I was violent and savage. It was only because of the pleas of my mother that the tribe did not slay me as an abomination while still an infant.

You don't understand. Not only am I different, I am half *orc*. The orcs are my tribe's most hated enemies; for generations they have warred with the Uthgardt. How could my tribe welcome me when I am a living reminder of their worst foe?
I... I never knew my father. My mother never spoke of him, though I saw the pain in her eyes whenever I asked. But where the pain came from, I could not say.

Some in our tribe said he was a vile beast who forced himself on my mother during a raid. Others claimed my mother loved him and welcomed him to her bed, then wept when he was murdered by the warriors who discovered them.

The truth I shall never know, for it died with my mother last winter. At her death the tribe cast me out. Can you blame them? Why waste good provisions on a half-breed bastard yet to prove himself in the world?

My mother died last year and her tribe cast me out. Perhaps they feared I might betray them because of my father's vile, tainted blood. Or perhaps my existence reminded them of the crimes of their past.
I... I never knew my father. My mother never spoke of him, though I saw the pain in her eyes whenever I asked. But where the pain came from, I could not say.

Some in our tribe said he was a vile beast who forced himself on my mother during a raid. Others claimed my mother loved him and welcomed him to her bed, then wept when he was murdered by the warriors who found them together in her tent.
Whatever the truth, it died with my mother. As did my link to the tribe. I am no longer welcome there. Can you blame them? A half-breed bastard child yet to prove himself to the world?

I bear my tribe no ill will. They had little choice; until I prove myself they cannot be certain where my loyalties lie. Once I show the spirit of the Uthgardt is pure within me the Red Tiger tribe will welcome me back.
It is as you say. Until I prove myself the tribe cannot be certain where my loyalties lie. Once I show the spirit of the Uthgardt is pure within me the Red Tiger tribe will welcome me back.

And it is not as if they abandoned me in the cold. They gave me food and weapons before they sent me out into the world to prove myself. And a sacred talisman of the tribe once carried by my mother...
You are a half-orc, <FirstName>. You know the hatred that follows our kind. You know how the world sees us.
I thank you for your kind offer, but there is little you can do for me right now.
If I cannot turn to a fellow half-orc for help, then who in this world can I turn to? There is something troubling me, <FirstName>.
My quest to prove my worth as an Uthgardt warrior has not yet begun, and already I fear I have failed.
We are both warriors, after all. If I cannot turn to my <brother/sister>-in-arms for aid, who in this world can I count on? There is something troubling me, <FirstName>.
If I cannot turn to a fellow adventurer, who in this world can I turn to? There is something troubling me, <FirstName>.
I am not the first Red Tiger warrior to be exiled in this way, though most who undertake a vision quest do so as punishment for committing some crime or transgression against the tribe.
I would tell you the details of my quest, <FirstName>, if I knew them myself. However, the quest is not known to me yet.
When the warrior is sent from the tribe he is given a special talisman. This talisman must remain by his side, for its magic brings the visions, and the visions illuminate his quest.
My talisman was a simple brooch worn by my mother, one of sentimental and spiritual value. Alas, I fear my quest will never be complete now, as the talisman - the key to my visions - is lost.
It happened shortly after I started work at the docks. I tried to keep a vigilant guard over the talisman, but the district is crawling with pickpockets and cutpurses.

Ever since it was stolen I have sought the brooch, but how can one locate such an object? It is unique, but of little monetary value. It may be that the thief who stole it threw it away when he realized how little it was worth.
Thank you, <FirstName>. But for now we should return to the task at hand. Aribeth is counting on you.
Of course not, <sir/madam>. My blade is yours to command, as always.
I am afraid I cannot be much help in this matter, <FirstName>. I know a little of the docks district but otherwise I know nothing of the city.
I cannot begin to guess where the cult we seek is hiding, though I suspect such evil could be found in the streets of Luskan.
I have little knowledge of these lands. My tribe is far from here, though I did pass through the Elk tribe territory near Fort Ilkard on my journey to Neverwinter.
When I first came to Neverwinter I worked as a guard in the docks district. It was a den of filth and sin, crawling with every kind of criminal. When the plague came things got even worse.
Ships were quarantined, trapping the crews in the city; many of these men are pirates and brigands. The numbers of dishonorable, dangerous men in the district swelled.
Between this and the plague, the city guard lost control of the district. Thugs and thieves rule the docks now.
Yes, we must get back to your mission. Aribeth is counting on you.
Before I left I heard talk of an auction to be held at Jim Seedy's tavern. Something unusual; not the standard contraband and slaves.
The word spread quickly on the street. Perhaps I could have learned more before I left, but I had no interest in such transactions. I am a warrior, not a smuggler.
There is nothing else I can think to tell you.
My mother's brooch! Thank you, <FirstName> - I can never repay you for this gift.
I have no gold or treasure to reward you, but there is one thing I can offer. A small token, perhaps, but it is all I have.
Because of you, <FirstName>, my vision quest can continue. I will keep my mother's brooch by my side so it may guide me on my quest.
But until I receive a vision to guide me on my quest I will remain by your side. Once more I thank you for finding my mother's brooch, <FirstName>.
I wish I had more to give you, <FirstName>. I know it might not look like much, but among the Uthgardt such an offering is considered a great gift.
That city is an evil place. Thieves and killers walk the streets in broad daylight, and gangs of thugs spread fear and violence in the name of the High Captains.

Luskan is run by several High Captains who each control sections of the city. An uneasy truce exists between these groups most of the time, but skirmishes and battles between the different factions are common.
If not for the threat of the Arcane Brotherhood, the High Captains' simmering rivalry would boil over into open warfare.
I understand. We must keep our efforts focused on rooting out those responsible for the Neverwinter plague.
The wizards and necromancers of the Brotherhood are the true rulers of Luskan, or so it is said. The seat of Luskan's power lies in the dark bowels of the Host Tower, base of the Arcane Brotherhood.
I don't really know any more about the Arcane Brothers. There are some secrets in the world I am content not to delve into.
I don't know if the cult we seek is in Luskan, <FirstName>, but I do know the city is a dangerous, violent place. More than that I can't really say.
I suppose the only way to find anything out for sure is to investigate. Rumors and guesses won't get us any closer to finding the cult.

The Elk tribe are of the Uthgardt people, as was my mother's own tribe, though their territory is to the south of Neverwinter. Like all the Uthgardt they are hunters and warriors who live off the land.
I have only met the leader of the Elk Tribe once, a great chieftain named Zokan Thunderer. He struck me as a noble and honorable man - a true Uthgardt.
I cannot imagine why the Elk tribe would suddenly ally itself with the Luskan forces. I sense there is something more to this, <FirstName>.
We Uthgardt are warriors, not savages. It is not our way to slaughter settlers and wage war upon Fort Ilkard without justification.
There is something strange behind the Elk tribe's alliance with Luskan. The only way you will solve this mystery, <FirstName>, is by going to Fort Ilkard.
After we parted ways in Neverwinter, I returned to the Trade of Blades to offer my skills for hire. It was there I was approached by Lady Aribeth on behalf of Lord Nasher himself.
Our instructions were simply to make ourselves available to whomever requires our assistance. So, in that spirit, is there anything I can do for you?
That city has long been an enemy of Neverwinter. An evil blight upon the North, it is widely acknowledged as the home of murders and thieves - a place with no honor!
It would not surprise me to discover links to the cult in that den of evil. Is there anything else I can help you with, <FirstName>?
I am eager to have my revenge on the cult that loosed its plague on Neverwinter.
I am Daelan Red Tiger, a noble warrior of the Uthgardt Red Tiger tribe. No doubt you are here on the same mission Aarin Gend has assigned to me and my fellow mercenaries: to find the Words of Power.
The Elk tribe has allied itself with the Luskan forces. As incredible as it sounds, they have attacked Fort Ilkard and the settlers' farms to the south.
I am of the Red Tiger tribe, but there are values and beliefs common to all the Uthgardt people. We are warriors and hunters, not bloodthirsty savages. The Uthgardt are a people of honor.
I believe some evil force is at work, a dark taint that has polluted the noble spirit of the Elk tribe. There can be no other explanation for their actions.
The Elk tribe has allied itself with the Luskan forces. As incredible as it sounds, they have attacked Fort Ilkard and the settlers' farms to the south.
I am of the Red Tiger tribe, but there are values and beliefs common to all the Uthgardt people. We are warriors and hunters, not bloodthirsty savages. The Uthgardt are a people of honor.
I believe some evil force is at work - a dark taint that has polluted the noble spirit of the Elk tribe. There can be no other explanation for their actions.
I only mention the Elk tribe because you ask, <FirstName>. If you allow me to join you once more, I will of course follow wherever you choose to go.

I know nothing of my father; my mother would never speak of him. But I was raised among the Red Tiger tribe in the customs and traditions of the Uthgardt people. I do not know what more I can tell you.
We Uthgardt are a simple but noble people. We hunt the herds and live off the land; we worship the gods of our ancestors and the totems of our tribes.
It was the closest city to our tribe, though I knew nothing of its foul, rotten character. If I had I would not have gone.
I have tried to forget my time in that accursed city, <FirstName>. The memories are not... pleasant.
As I told you, I went to Luskan in search of glory and honor - but there is no honor to be found in that wretched city.
At first I found a warm welcome in Luskan. Half-orcs are accepted there as nowhere else, and I quickly found work as a soldier serving one of the High Captain rulers of the city.
It was bloody, brutal work. Soldiers from different factions were always battling in the streets. Many men died by my hand during my weeks there.
I killed them because I was paid to kill them. Because they served a different master. There was no honor in these battles, <FirstName>. Only senseless, shameful death.

You don't understand, <FirstName>. All the killing, all the bloodshed - I *liked* it. It stirred my soul. Each morning I could taste the coming battles on my tongue and feel the rush of combat in my veins.
I reveled in the slaughter like an animal, like a beast. It fed the dark taint of my father's orc blood, and left a stain on my soul.
I do not know how far I would have fallen, had fate not intervened and saved me from myself.
My fury in battle earned me a promotion, and I was sent to the Luskan flesh markets to guard the slaves in their stockades.

My first night at the stockades, the guards brought in a new batch of slaves. Among them was an old man, naked and feeble. I recognized the tattoos on his face as the markings of an Uthgardt holy man.
I did not know him; he was from another tribe. But seeing him brought in, hands shackled behind his back, brought shame crashing down upon me.
At first I did nothing. The old man looked at me as he passed, and I saw in his eyes that he knew I was of the Uthgardt - and he knew what I had become.
Without warning the old man threw himself at the nearest guard; a foolish gesture of defiance, for he was still shackled and bound. He was knocked to the floor, and the guards began to beat him.
My world vanished beneath a veil of blood-red rage. When I came to my senses I stood bathed in gore; the other guards in the stockade all lay dead by my hand.

The old man lay bleeding on the floor, stabbed by one of the guards during the fight. As I crouched over him I saw his wounds were fatal. He gazed up at me and spoke in a voice choked with blood: 'Free the others.'
With my axe I hacked away the chains of the other slaves in the stockades. Once they had all fled into the night I returned to the old man's side.
I thank you for your words, <FirstName>. And I would like to believe you. But I know what I did in Luskan. I know what vile appetites I fed.
I cannot deny my father's blood is within me. I can only hope to overcome this blight so that I may someday prove my spirit worthy of the Uthgardt.
Only then will my tribe welcome me back. Until then this is my burden to bear... one of many.
I know the bloodlust is within me. I know what I am, <FirstName>, but I cannot accept it.
Your words are unduly harsh, but you need not fear, <FirstName>. My blade shall never fail you in your time of need.
Forgive me, <FirstName>. You have been a good friend to listen to my tale, but there are some things I am not yet ready to share with you.
I was not completely honest with you about the reasons I left my tribe. It is true I was sent away to prove myself. But there was another reason as well.
My mother's death was a violent one; she was brutally slain in a bandit raid on our camp. And I have vowed not to return to my tribe until I avenge her murder.
I was out hunting with a band of warriors when the attack came. The raiders hid and waited for us to leave, and then sneaked in with the advantage of numbers.
My tribe was outnumbered nearly two to one, but they managed to drive the attackers off. Three of our warriors fell in the battle - as did my mother.
Do you remember when I told you of my vision quest - how my mother's brooch would bring me dreams to guide my quest? Last night I had a dream.

My mother's spirit sent me this vision, I am certain of it. In my dream I saw a terrible axe dripping blood from its notched blade; it was the weapon used to slay her. If I can find the axe I will know I have found her killer.
You may think me a fool, <FirstName>, but I believe I will find that axe. I must, or my mother's spirit will never truly be at peace!
You need not concern yourself. I shall follow your commands as always, <FirstName>.
Thank you, <FirstName>. With a friend like you by my side I have no doubt my mother's death will be avenged.
They told me there was a sinister dwarf among the bandits - one of many who escaped the battle. Then it is... over. My mother is avenged, and her spirit can finally rest.
Thank you, <FirstName> - once again you have proven yourself to be the greatest of friends. Words cannot properly explain the... the gratitude I feel.
I regret that I can offer you nothing as a reward but my thanks, my friendship, and my courage in battle.
Thank you again, <FirstName>. My mother is avenged and her spirit is at peace.
As I said, I regret I can give you nothing more. Now let us return to the task at hand. My mother is avenged, but those behind the Wailing Death must still be dealt with!
There are even those who say she was driven mad by Fenthick's execution, and is not aware of what she's doing. But I think something else drives her now.
And then lord Nasher sent her to Port Llast with Aarin Gend. It was obvious Lord Nasher wanted an excuse to send her away from the city.
I am not saying what Aribeth did was right, or even justified. But there is a tale among the Uthgardt, an ancient legend of consequences and betrayal.
Fenthick's execution and Aribeth's betrayal remind me of a tale of my own people. I only hope Neverwinter does not suffer the same fate as the Uthgardt.
Many of my people's customs would be familiar to you, <FirstName>. We too are called barbarians, for we are tribal hunters and warriors who live off the land.
In ancient times all the Uthgardt tribes were one, a mighty nation under the great hero-king Uthgar.
Our people were indomitable in battle - none dared stand against Uthgar when he wielded his great spear. It is said no weapon could harm him when he brandished the spear over his head.

But against our greatness the armies of our enemies massed - goblins, orcs, ogres, and other creatures too foul to mention. A dark host marched forth from the mountains to battle Uthgar and his people.
According to the tale, there was a young boy who desired nothing more than to be a great hero of the Uthgardt. When news of the invasion came, he swore he would join the ranks of men as a warrior.
He was a mere child, not even a youth, and the warriors told him to stay with the woman and infants. But the boy was brave and stubborn, and he would not accept this.
The night before the battle, the boy crept into Uthgar's tent and stole his magic spear. Then the boy marched out in the darkness to face the horde alone.

But he was a child. He did not even know where he was going, and he soon became lost in the woods. In the morning, Uthgar woke to find his spear gone. He was forced to march against the enemy without it.

The battle raged fierce and bloody and many warriors fell before the enemy broke and fled. But even victory came with a terrible cost, for Uthgar - father of our people - was felled by an arrow through the eye.

After many days the boy found his way back to the camp. Those who saw him with the spear quickly understood what had happened and they blamed him for Uthgar's death. They cast him out forever, banishing him from the tribe.
The boy fled, taking the spear with him. He had only wanted to prove himself a warrior, he had only wanted to help defend the tribe. His motives were honorable.
But his actions had tragic consequences, and the Uthgardt could not forgive him. Just as Neverwinter could not forgive Fenthick. But the tale does not end there.
The boy vanished; he was never seen again - and neither was Uthgar's Spear, the symbol and source of the Uthgardt nation's power and might.
Without the spear my people were vulnerable, and our enemies fell upon us. The great nation of the Uthgardt was splintered into small tribes. Never again would we know the glory of our past.
Had the Uthgardt forgiven the boy, he and the spear would have remained and the empire would have stayed strong. Had Neverwinter forgiven Fenthick, Aribeth might not have betrayed the city she loved.
There is more to the legend of Uthgar's Spear, <FirstName>.
As you know, I am on a vision quest to prove myself a true Uthgardt warrior. Last night I had a vision to guide me on my quest.
I have seen the spear in my dreams. According to the legends of my people, the Uthgardt tribes will never be united until Uthgar's Spear is found.
I have come to believe it is the will of the gods that I stay by your side. You found my mother's brooch; you avenged her murder. I cannot help but feel you are destined to help me in this as well.
Thank you, <FirstName>. Your promise means much to me, for you are a <man/woman> of true honor. I know my quest will end in success.
But for now we must focus on finding the Words of Power. Aarin Gend is counting on us.
I have vowed to serve you as long as you have need of my blade, <FirstName>. I will not forsake that vow.
Yes - this is the spear from my dreams! Uthgar's Spear! Because of you I can return to my people with proof my spirit is worthy of the Red Tiger tribe!
The talisman has powerful magical properties, though I know it is hardly a suitable reward for all you have done for me. Alas, the only other thing I can offer you is my continued service.
I long to return to my people, <FirstName>, and reclaim my place among my tribe. But I will not abandon you, or break my promise to serve.
As long as you have need of me I will stay by your side and aid you in the search for the Words of Power. Only after they have been recovered will I return to my tribe.
I suspect the Uthgardt are much like your people, <FirstName>. We are both barbarians, are we not?
But I also vow that I will not rest until I find the axe with the notched blade that slew my mother.
Now let us return to the task at hand - those behind the Wailing Death must still be dealt with!
I will bring Uthgar's Spear back to my tribe and present it to our Council of Elders. I have no doubt they will declare my spirit worthy of the Red Tiger tribe.
I imagine my chieftain will summon an inter-tribal council so that all the Uthgardt tribes will know the artifact has been found. This is an event of great importance to my people, <FirstName>.
According to the legends, the return of Uthgar's Spear heralds the return of Uthgar himself, to be born among our tribes. They say it signals a return to the glory of our ancient past.
I cannot say for certain. Perhaps I will be hailed as a hero and showered with riches and honors by the chieftains of my people.
Or perhaps I will simply be welcomed back into the tribe. The elders could allow me to take a wife and raise a son of my own amongst the Uthgardt people.
Either would be pleasing to me, <FirstName>. I have proven myself worthy and for the first time I feel truly at peace with my place in the world.
I am beginning to wonder if I chose a poor <master/mistress> to serve. I became... lost in the moment. It will not happen again.
Your words are cruel, <FirstName>. You speak the truth, but you do so only to hurt. Among my people such cruelty is frowned upon.
I think we need to change your tactics.
I think I'll do better off on my own.
I want to change the distance you stay away from me.
Stay close.
Keep a medium distance.
Stay a long distance away from me.
Nevermind.
I want to change our agreement about when you heal me.
Heal me when I drop below 75% of my total hit points.
Heal me when I drop below 50% of my total hit points.
Heal me when I drop below 25% of my total hit points.
Stop searching all the time.
Search while we move.
Travel in stealth mode from now on.
Stop traveling in stealth mode.
Help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest.
Don't help me if I fail to open a locked door or chest.
I don't want to change anything else right now.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 100.
We need change way you do stuff.
Me no want you here no more.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 100 only.
I could use a good rogue. Here's your 150 gold. Welcome aboard, Tomi.
Here be you 150 gold. Now you be me slave, Tomi.
I'll be going now.
Me go now.
125? Deal.
I could use a good rogue. Here's your 200 gold. Welcome aboard, Tomi.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 150.
Here be 200 gold. Now you be me slave, Tomi.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 150 only.
I could use a good rogue. Here's your 250 gold. Welcome aboard, Tomi.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seems a little expensive. I'll give you 200.
Here be 250 gold. Now you be me slave, Tomi.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> That seem high. Me give 200 only.
175? Deal.
225? Deal.
You change how far away you stay.
You need change how you heal me.
You not search all time no more.
You search all time when we move.
You stop sneaking so quiet now.
You start sneak quiet now.
If me fail on locked door or chest you help me.
If me fail on locked door or chest you not help me.
Me not want change anything else now.
You heal if me sort of hurt (below 75% of total hit points).
You heal if me wounded (below 50% of total hit points).
You heal if me hurt real bad (below 25% of total hit points).
Yes. Go.
No. Stay.
I don't have that kind of gold to spend on a henchman.
Me not got that much gold for spend on you.
Who are you?
I don't feel like talking right now. Goodbye.
How did you escape the prison?
I'm looking for a good rogue to help me in my mission.
I work for Lady Aribeth. I have been instructed to find several missing creatures that might be used to find a plague cure.
I work for Lady Aribeth. My mission is confidential.
Why would the warden release the prisoners?
Actually, I'm looking for some hired help to assist me on my mission.
No thanks. Goodbye.
I want to ask you some questions.
Well, I wasn't acting alone.
Yes, that would be me.
Who you be?
Me not wanna talk. Goodbye.
How you escapes prison?
Me looking for rogue to help on mission.
Why warden lets everyone go?
Me looking for help in me mission.
Me go now.
Me work for lady Aribeth. Me looking for creatures. They are important. They cure plague.
Me working for lady Aribeth. Can't tell you me mission. It secret.
Me want to ask questions.
Me have lots of help!
Me greatest one there is! Me save city!
So you're working for Aribeth?
Goodbye.
You work for Aribeth? Me work for Aribeth too!
(Sluuurp) Oops, me sorry. So how you get hired by Aribeth?
Do you intend to just sit around here, then?
You going to just sit around, huh?
I wouldn't mind an extra body. You're in.
Sorry, but I'm not interested. Goodbye.
Me need another man. You in.
Sorry, me not interested.
Have you heard any rumors about the cult since you've come here?
You hear any stuff about cult? Me looking for clues.
Luskan?
So are you going to look into it some more?
So why are you standing around here? Shouldn't you be out scouring the North for this cult?
You gonna try to find out more stuff about the cult and Luskan?
Why you stand around here? You supposed to be looking for cult.
I'd like you to level up. You'd be more useful to me with a little training.
Me want you to level up. You be better with training.
I just want to talk.
Me just wanna talk.
I'd like to know a little more about you.
Continue your story from before.
Nevermind.
Me wanna know you better. Me think that important.
You continue you story from before.
If we're to be companions I'd like to know more about you.
I'd like you to continue your story from before, Tomi.
If we be travel together, me want know more 'bout you.
Me want you keep talking 'bout story you start before.
Have you always been a rogue, Tomi?
I want you to continue your story from before.
You always be rogue, Tomi?
Me want you to continue you story from before.
You again? Are you following me around?
I'm surprised to see you here, Tomi.
So you were conscripted into service by Aribeth?
How much would it cost to hire your services?
Goodbye.
I could use a good rogue by my side.
Do you have any information on the cult behind the Wailing Death?
I don't need anything right now.
I did my duty.
I know, I'm great. What can I say?
Me do duty.
Me am so great! Me am so great!
So you're working for Aarin Gend?
You work for Aarin Gend? Me work for Aarin too!
Goodbye.
Have you heard any rumors as to where the Words could be?
Why are you standing around here? Shouldn't you be looking for these Words?
You heard any rumors about where Words be? Me want to find them.
Why you stand here? You should look for Words.
I could use some stealth in my search for the Words.
Sorry, I'm not interested.
You look like sneaky guy. Me could use you in me search for Power Words.
Me not like you.
It is good to see you again, Tomi.
I'm getting sick of seeing you every time I turn around!
Do you know anything about the Words of Power, Tomi?

You betrayed her. I wouldn't take it well, either.
Why didn't you just kill the mage and run off with the girl?
What did she do about it?
You betrays her. Me not like betrays, neither.
Why you not kills mage and runs off with girl?

Well, don't even think about betraying me, got it?
Me not see how this makes you famous.
You no think to betrays me like that!

I think I see where this is going...
I don't believe a word of it.
Oooh, that not sounds good.
Me thinking me knows where this goes...

You fought him then, I take it?
So he catches you with daughter? You defends her honor?

And this make you famous?

She angry 'cause you kill daddy?

Perhaps we'll find your friend, yet.

Maybe we finds your friend somehow.

Me finds papers. This them?

What happen to Sammy?

You're all heart, Tomi.
Me has ruby. This ruby you looks for?

Hmm... I'm not sure I want your friendship, considering what happened to Sammy...

Hmm... me not sure me wants to be friend, like Sammy...

You no let it stops stuff you does for me!

So you stole them?

Me sure wizard means to be good to you.

That horrible! You no feels bad?

I have these ashes of an Uthgardt hero... would they serve?

Keep your mind on your duty to me.

Me haves ashes of Uthgardt. Maybe they's okay?

I rather doubt you'll find anyone else of my skill available, m'<lord/lady>. You seem like a fine sort of <man/woman>, however, so let me say, ummm, 150 gold pieces?

If you feel that's best. What would you like to change?
Oh? How far do you want me?

Wha-aat? Are you kidding me? You want to break up a great team?
Well, fine. Tomi Undergallows has better things to do. I'm sure someone will hire me any day now.

Why, hullo there! You have the smell of a prospective employer about you, m'<lord/lady>. Not that it's easy to smell anything with all the burning corpses in this city, mind you. Never seen this many flies outside of a Calimshite alehouse.
Good, good! I smell adventure at hand! Or I need to wash my socks, one of the two...
I rather doubt you'll find anyone else of my skill available, m'<lord/lady>. 200 gold pieces seems like a fair bargain, don't you agree?
I rather doubt you'll find anyone else of my skill available, m'<lord/lady>. I think, ummm, 250 gold pieces should be sufficient.
Oh dear, it seems that the brain squirrels have been storing their nuts again.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Hmmm... how about we split the difference. 125?

I'll tag along with you, m'<lord/lady>, as best as I know how... unless you tell me otherwise. If you want me to do something different, just give me a shout, aye?
I rather doubt you'll find anyone else of my skill available, m'<lord/lady>. Tell you what, however... since you're a fellow halfling, I'll be glad to work out a deal. 150 gold pieces.
