Fair enough. Back to the adventure!
Oh, fine, fine. I'll hang about here for a little while, then, just in case you change your mind.
If you feel that is best. What would you like to change?
How far away do you want me to stay?
All righty! Close it is. Just make sure you keep up with the laundry, aye?
Okey-dokey. Medium distance it is.
What? Do I smell? Well, fine, have it your way, m'<lord/lady>.
Something else?
Something else?
You're the boss.
But what if we miss something? Like... like gold! But fine, fine... I won't argue with ya.
I can do that! Consider my beady little eyes peeled!
Yep. Just remember that I'm still about, okay? The high-pitched scream will be me.
Hmph. Well I guess I don't have to skulk *all* the time.
Absolutely! My lockpicks are twirling and ready to go!
I guess if you *think* you don't need my help...
You were expecting me to work for free? What do I look like? An elf?! Pfffft! Come back when you find a few coins.
So you've come back, m'<lord/lady>! Looking for a short lad to tickle your feet? Or did ya change your mind about needing a rogue at your side?
Hullo there! <FullName>, isn't it? Wow... the savior of Neverwinter! Would you sign my napkin? It's a bit greasy... and mind the chicken...
Heya, m'<lord/lady>! Decided to wander back to Tomi Undergallows once again, did ya?
Well, now, if it isn't <FirstName>! Glad I am to see you! Isn't the country wonderful this time of year? So much better than the city with all that... umm... burning and dying. You know.
Heya, m'<lord/lady>. You're that <FirstName>, ain't ya? Mister Gend told me you're some kind of hero, the savior of Neverwinter or sommat.
Nice to see ya again, m'<lord/lady>. That cheerful Gend fellow brought you here, too, huh? Looking for some Words of Power or sommat?
Hullo again, m'<lord/lady>. Decided you gots need for a sneak-thief to accompany you now, huh?
I figured they'd drag your carcass back here eventually, m'<lord/lady>. You need me to come with ya again?
Sorry... I'm here with someone else, don't'cha know.

It was so strange, m'<lord/lady>... there was this bright tunnel, and my mother was there... and then it was like 'yoink! Not yet, stupid!' and I was back here. Weird, huh? So do ya need my help again?
So let's negotiate a bit, shall we? I can place my superior skills of theft, lockpicking and swordplay at your disposal for any task you choose, providing you can provide me with a nice payment now.
IGNORE THIS STARTING CONDITION. THIS IS USED AS A TRASH FOR UNWANTED LINKS. DO NOT DELETE THESE LINKS.
Oops! I hear that's the first sign of the plague. Tsk. If you don't die some wretched death, m'<lord/lady>, come back sometime and we'll make a deal, aye?
I can forgive you for not having heard of me, however. I hail most recently from Calimport... and that's a long way for even my reputation to travel. I give it another week, personally.
Fortunately, my stay in Neverwinter's fine prison system was a short one. I didn't arrange for my escape, oddly enough, but I was glad for it nevertheless.

Oh? A mission, is it? My little pinky toes are quivering with curiosity! Or is that my danger sense? Hmm... that would go a long way toward explaining my recklessness. Oh well. What kind of mission are you on?
So not only a mission, but a legitimate heroic deed performed for the benefit of a cute elf. I hear ya, m'<lord/lady>. I'd be glad to help out... for the right price.
Ahhh, which makes you some kind of secret agent for the lovely elven lass? Must be exciting! I'd be glad to help out... for the right price.

The exact goings-on within the prison I'm not entirely aware of, m'<lord/lady>. To tell the truth, I had only been in the prison for a few days and was just starting to think about how depressing life was when it all began.
I really can't say. Some of the other fellows were talking like there was some powerful prisoner who was controlling the warden and making him do these things... sounds too strange to me.
Come to think of it, I saw more than a few people getting attacked in the street in broad daylight. If you head to that part of town, you might want to take someone along who knows the roads, aye?

I know a little bit about the Peninsula district, however. It's all a bit fleeting, seeing as I was running through it at the time, but what do you expect from someone who escaped from the prison there?

Modesty, eh? How's that working out for ya? If I were you, I'd take advantage of the notoriety while you have it. Three months from now they'll turn you away from the door at McBarnaby's, saying "<FirstName> who?"
Me, I'm Tomi Undergallows. Grin to my friends... Tomi Grin to my other friends. I've been hired by Miss Aribeth, there, to help find these nasty cultist-types.
Yes, I... know that. You're drooling on my napkin, m'<lord/lady>...
Uh-huh. Toodle-loo!
Seems like Lord Nasher wants to get rid of all the cultists who started this fight. I say good for him! Just goes to show that not all old people are useless and should be killed, you know?
Anyhow, Miss Aribeth heaped a bunch of coin on me to come join this search. Pretty sweet job, so far.
Well, I wouldn't get a lot done running off on my own, m'<lord/lady>. Heck, I was just told to come here and wait until somebody needed me.
I'm no hero like you are, m'<lord/lady>... though I am a darn good rogue, if I do say so myself.
This town is kind of boring. So far I've counted fourteen chickens that crossed the road. I suppose, if you needed me, I'd be happy to tag along with ya.
Nothing more than anyone, no. You ask me, though, Luskan's the place to look.
Oh, aye. The city has pirates and thieves galore... anyone with any kind of bad reputation is more than welcome there, I assure you. Been there a few times, myself.
What better place for a frog to hide than amongst toads? Not that I've any evidence to back that up, or anything.
All righty, then, m'<lord/lady>... I'm all yours. If ya need me to do something other than what I'm doing, just give me a shout.
I'm always useful. Seeing as I've gained a bit of skill, though, let me sit down for a moment... then I can show you what I can do now.
Oh? What did you have in mind, m'<lord/lady>?
Okey-dokey. We got plenty to keep us busy, anyway, I'm sure.
Well... maybe just a little. After all, it's not like there's enough employers alive right now that I have them beating down my door, aye? And anyway... I didn't have to chase you, much.
Yeah, well, what's a halfling supposed to do? Me, I go where the money is.
Seems like Lord Nasher wants to get rid of all the cultists who started this fight. I say good for him! Just goes to show that not all old people are useless and should be killed, you know?
I've already been paid by Miss Aribeth... and good coin, too, I might add. You'd think this Nasher fellow belched gold at will.
Okey-dokey! If you find yourself in need of a rougue, I'm already bought and paid for... just need to know where the party is.
Besides a bath? Suit yourself, m'<lord/lady>.
Well, isn't it a coincidence that I happen to be a good rogue? Fine... this one-rabbit town was beginning to bore me, anyway.
Nothing more than anyone, no. You ask me, though, Luskan's the place to look.
Uh-huh. Fame can be a tricky mistress, m'<lord/lady>. I should know, as Tomi's a halfling who's been on the lips of everyone in Calimport... an' paid the price, too.
Aye, m'<lord/lady>. Run off and do your hero business.
Well, I don't know if 'working' is really correct. I was, ah, caught doing something I shouldn't somewhere where I wasn't supposed to be. So Mister Gend didn't leave me much choice.
Not that I mind all that much, m'<lord/lady>. This is an easy job, come to think of it.
Me? Heck no. You might want to trot off to the Coldwood and check it out, though.
Sheesh. What do I look like? Some bloodhound? Tell ya what... if you need my help, I'd be happy to search with you, m'<lord/lady>.
Hokey-dokey, m'<lord/lady>.
Well, it's up to you, m'<lord/lady>. Trot on back if ya change your mind.
I was gonna take a long hike and look around for my old friend, Sammy... I bet he's around here somewheres... but somehow I knew we'd bump into each other again.
Well, it's not like I'm shadowing ya or anything, m'<lord/lady>. If I were, you wouldn't see me at all. Have it your way, though.
Well, to make the story short I kind of was caught doing something I shouldn't when I was somewhere I shouldn't have been... so Mister Gend said I had to come and help here, or else.
Figures that you'd be here, too, m'<lord/lady>, with you being a great hero and all. Bet you didn't have to come like I did, either.
Hokey-dokey, m'<lord/lady>.
Well, it's up to you, m'<lord/lady>. Trot on back if ya change your mind.
Me? Heck no. You might want to trot off to the Coldwood and check it out, though.
Great! Let's, um, avoid that tunnel for a bit, though, aye?
Okey-dokey. You know where I'll be.
Lead the way!
Well, you know where I'll be, then.
You know how it goes, I'm sure. Rob some over-fat human caliph with piggy lips, kiss his daughter as a lark before you escape with the loot, and suddenly you're the most wanted man in Calimshan.
How was I supposed to know that he was so sensitive about his daughter? I still say it was worth it. That took flair, and I have flair! Too bad Neverwinter didn't treat me any better, at first.
Nothing too wrong with having a bit of a reputation, m'<lord/lady>. Keeps the flies from settling, if you know what I mean. If the heat gets too high, you just step out of the kitchen, right?
Neverwinter seemed a fine enough city for an enterprising young halfling like myself... on the surface, anyway. You'd be surprised at what people get away with, here.
They can take a perfectly innocent man, accuse him of simple pickpocketing, and throw him in prison without even so much as a trial. Or not a very fair one, anyway. That judge was mean.
More likely he was brain-sick with the plague. The entire Peninsula district is in an uproar, however. I don't think the local constabulary has it under control, either.

Unless you're sneaking up for a good backstab or in the sack with a pretty miss, I really don't see the need for restraint. Silence is for the dead... although I hear they can be a bit chatty, too, at times.
Questions, eh? To be honest, I'm not that big on Neverwinter just yet. I was trying to make some contacts earlier, but they just kept *dying*. How annoying is that?

I left the area quickly, of course, and wound up here at the temple... nice safe place t' be. Last I heard, them prisoners were all tearing up the Peninsula district, making a royal mess. Mmm, not the lawyers, though... they were just overcharging.
Hmm. I guess I can tell you a bit about the Peninsula district, if you want... but I'm not very familiar with the rest of the city.
Well, if I was a cult, you know where I would hide? Luskan. The City of Sails, home to every pirate, smuggler, lawyer and all-around ne'er-do-well north of Waterdeep.
Whoa... I don't know much about these areas, myself. I'm just following you, remember, m'<lord/lady>? Although I guess I know a bit about the Coldwood...
Well... the prison itself be the most prominent part of the district, aye? Anything interesting that goes on there is bound to be tied up with the prison, somehow.
When I escaped, a bunch of the fellows being held there had taken the warden over... and the prison, too. There was something fishy about the whole thing.
You'd think the city guard would take control of the prison back... but they've got too much on their plate with the plague, I guess.
Okey-dokey.
No, I don't think so, m'<lord/lady>. Best to avoid the district altogether.
I mean, who would notice a few extra murders in a place like that? Last time I was there, if the pirates weren't chopping people up in the streets, the High Captains were.
Aye. There be five High Captains, ex-pirates all, who rule the city with an iron fist. Why there's five and not just one, I have no idea.
Mind you, they don't really rule Luskan. Anyone who knows anything about Luskan knows that the Arcane Brotherhood really runs the show.
Hokey-dokey. You go do your hero thing, then.
Ahhh, it's just some group of evil wizards bent on dominating the world. You know... the usual wizard stuff. They're led by some guy called the 'Archmage Arcane', I think.
If I remember right, they're all bottled up in the Host Tower, which sits just off the coast on a little island. Never come out, very secretive... that sort of thing.
Well, Luskan's not a very welcoming place... especially for us demi-humans. It's mostly all just really nasty human folk with no better place to be.
If the cult is there, they could be anywhere, I'm guessing. Seems to me that somebody in Luskan would know something, though.
Well, I passed through there a few months back. Had a little gnome for a guide who talked and talked about the places we passed through. Couldn't get the little bugger to shut up, really.
There's some orcs round those parts who serve some great chieftain who calls himself a king. Obould or somethin'. Merciless and nasty fellow.
Anyway, he mentioned a few ruins in the woods. Really old ones, too. One of them belonged to a wizard who collected strange things... maybe she was fond of words? I don't know.
I hear they've been busy attacking merchants and caravans an' the like. Maybe they're mixed up with the cult, an' maybe they know more about them magic words. Worth a shot, I suppose.

My guide said there's lots of places in the Coldwood which are really old, places where nobody goes anymore. If these Words of Power are old and lost... I don't know, maybe it's the place to look for 'em.
After you and I went our separate ways, Miss Aribeth there approached me and gave me plenty of money to hop along on this pony ride of hers. We're all supposed to help with the search.
I was just told that I'm supposed to help out wherever I can. How sweet and unspecific is that? I, uh, don't suppose you actually want something, do you?
Oh, aye. The city has pirates and thieves galore... anyone with any kind of bad reputation is more than welcome there, I assure you. Been there a few times, myself.
What better place for a frog to hide than amongst toads? Not that I've any evidence to back that up, or anything.
This job of Miss Aribeth's... looking for them cult fellows... it's been pretty sweet so far. Haven't had to do much 'cept stare at people all suspicious-like.
But who am I to tell ya what to do? Mister Gend says you're here to do the same as the rest of us: find these Words of Power. I wonder if anyone's checked the library...
Well, there's always tales of strange things out in those woods. I passed through more than a month back, and I remember seeing some ruins off the path.
My guide said they belonged to some wealthy mage who locked herself away in there long ago... and that she used to collect a lot of strange things. So who knows?
I heard about a whole lot of orcs in the area, too, serving some big fella who calls himself King Obould. Could be they could tell ya about them magic words, who knows?
Well, there's always tales of strange things out in those woods. I passed through more than a month back, and I remember seeing some ruins off the path.
My guide said they belonged to some wealthy mage who locked herself away in there long ago... and that she used to collect a lot of strange things. So who knows?
Old acquaintance of mine is in that area, too. Name's Vaash. I wouldn't trust him further than I could throw him (which ain't far), but he knows the Coldwood well.
Well, you strike me as a bit of a rogue yourself, m'<lord/lady>. Sometimes a reputation deserves to be run from, aye? Like a giant ogre with big feet and poor eyesight.
Oh, I don't think the Calimshites would mind, m'<lord/lady>. The way they dress, it be a kindness to talk instead about their foul ale.
Oh, to be honest, m'<lord/lady>, I be far more frightened to take a swig of Calimshite ale. You'd be lucky to wake up three days later hugging the back end of a camel, I'd wager.
Heh... it means I be bloody glad to be out of Calimshan and anywhere else, even here! Now, about that employer business...
Me? Why, I'm none other than the renowned rogue, Tomi Undergallows! "Grin" to my friends, "Tomi Grin" to the lasses, and "that damned halfling" to anyone in a position of respectable authority.
Well, I use the word "kissing" loosely, m'<lord/lady>. Trouble was, the lass was set to marry the Pasha's son... so long as she was a virgin. Ah, well.
Technically, I suppose I am. Trust me, however: they have so many other things to worry about in that prison, even if they thought I wasn't dead they wouldn't trouble with me.
Considering my profession, that's quite a fine line you draw there. Have it your way, however. If you change your mind, we'll chat again.
The warden of the place began babbling some nonsense and started releasing all the prisoners. Even the truly despicable types: murderers, politicians, lawyers, you name it.
Aww, now that is a shame. Well, m'<lord/lady>, don't let zombies eat your brains or anything. I hear it's bad for one's health.
Oh? It's a bit strange to have you ask me that, m'<lord/lady>. Most people think they know Tomi Undergallows well enough through his reputation.
In Calimport, the tales of my deeds were the daily fodder of old men in the taverns. I do not speak of heroic acts, however... I am a halfling of the underworld, if you remember.
Ha ha! Don't get me wrong, m'<lord/lady>... I may not be the heroic type, but it's not as if I run about stealing children and kicking puppies.
No, no, Tomi Undergallows may follow the scent of gold and fame wherever it leads, but I've no dastardly tales to singe the ears off the pious just yet.
Then you're a <man/woman> after my own heart. While there's often good reasons to do anything, the best are always gold and fame.
I've done plenty, myself, in search of those two. Had both in ample quantities and lost them more than once, you know.
Oh, nothing so sordid and evil as you might guess. I've had fame and fortune a'plenty more than once... and lost it all just as often.
My most famous exploit, in fact, is one of the reasons I chose to come to Neverwinter when I fled from Calimshan.

You see, I'd spent the larger part of my years in Calimport in the employ of a powerful medusa. She was a great power in the city's underworld and that is no small feat for anyone, statue-making gaze or no.
Quite serious. She had a fine head for business and was as ruthless as any cold-hearted shiyk. Not as good with the face-to-face negotiations, though, if you take my meaning.
True. She was a spiteful one, I'll grant you that. Had a great head for business, though, and a bad hair day that could bite you back.
I was in her employ to run... errands. Burglaries, message deliveries, walking her cat, assassinations, that sort of thing. I did my job well, too, and was well-known for it.
The job that made me famous, however, was the last one she gave me. I was to infiltrate the house of the famous vizier Sabbalan Viheyed... and kill him!
If it's any consolation, m'<lord/lady>, I doubt I killed anyone who didn't deserve it. In Calimport, you do what you can to survive.
I was, though not in the manner you're probably suspecting. There's far more to that story than I've told.
We've business to undertake, I suppose. Perhaps I'd best tell the rest of the story another time. What do you say to that, m'<lord/lady>?
Wow, you're more impatient than a drunk cameldriver in line at the salt market, aren't you? Ask me another time and I'll tell ya everything.
Hokey-dokey. Lead on, m'<lord/lady>!
Well, as I recall, you are the one who asked... so that's entirely up to you. Lead on!
What's this? Oh, right. Where was I? Was I telling you about my infiltration of the house of the great vizier Sabbalan Viheyed? Yes, I believe I was.
This was no ordinary mission, my friend. Sabbalan had stymied the efforts of my medusan patroness for many years... he was a mage of no little power.
Sending me to kill him was both a vote of confidence in my abilities and, I thought, a near-certain sentence of death. Looking me in the eyes would have been cleaner.
It was not as if I were given a choice. With my patroness, you had the option of succeeding or of becoming the newest addition to her garden statuary.

Oh, yes, of course. To be honest it was what I lived for at the time. Tomi the Daring, they called me! The possibility of being turned into a statue if I failed did put things into perspective, to boot.
I did say it was the job that made me famous, didn't I? And anyway... the threat of being turned into a short statue was rather an incentive to succeed.
Perhaps it's fortunate that us halflings aren't given much credit. I was able to squirm my way into the vizier's service as a kitchen boy, and nobody gave me a second thought.
For over a month, I was pleased to serve the vizier his meals. I spent my time studying him, looking for a way to kill him cleanly... and he barely even noticed my presence.
I would have, I suppose... except that he ate his meals with his daughter, and that made things a bit complicated.
Normally, yes. The vizier ate his meals with his daughter, however, and er... she did notice me.
About the vizier? No, not really. He was a cruel man with political ambitions. His daughter, on the other hand... well, that's a different story.
His daughter... ahhh, the sweet lass. Saida was her name. Human, to be sure, but she never looked down upon me.
I suppose I delayed killing Sabbalan at the time just to continue being around her, though I didn't think that at the time. There was just one more excuse after another.

The months grew longer, and Saida and I grew closer. She couldn't resist my charms, of course, heh... no lass can, when I put my mind to it. We had to be secret about it... I was, of course, just the kitchen boy.
Oh, aye, I dreaded the thought of it, but my patroness was already threatening to turn me into a statue and let the pigeons have their way with me.
Oh, aye. I couldn't let Saida find out who I was... yet my patroness was growing impatient. Wait too long and I'd be a Tomi statue with the pigeons having their way with me.
Oh, I don't know about that. I thought so at the time, sure enough. My patroness kept threatening to turn me into a statue and let the pigeons have their way with me, however.

I was young and foolish and stupid, however... three traits that are great in a buxom lass but poor in an assassin. I decided I couldn't hurt Saida by killing her father and told my patroness to go look in the mirror.
Needless to say, she didn't take it well.
Well, she's an evil woman with snakes for hair and a look that killed... what do you think she did about it?
The girl wasn't going anywhere... trust me, I tried. Come to think of it, the mage wasn't all that easy to kill, either...
Well, fortunately you don't turn your closest friends into pottery. My patroness wasn't exactly the life of the party, you know.
My medusa patroness decided to take matters into her own hands, of course. Heh... if I'd known, I would have left Calimport a lot earlier.
Hey, hey hey! Slow down there, m'<lord/lady>! Don't you go getting ahead of yourself or anything, sheesh.
It certainly didn't look that way at the time, I'll grant you that, m'<lord/lady>.
At any rate... it's a bit of a story. I'll tell you the rest some other time. Let's just keep on with your quest, for now.
Oh, fine, fine. Picture this, then, m'<lord/lady>: there I was lying in the arms of my human sweetie, completely unaware my angry patroness was on her way.
I was also unaware that at the same time my sweetie's father, the vizier, had been tipped off to my presence by an old rival of mine.
Both the wizard and the medusa were descending on the tower determined to kill me, and I was contentedly asleep in the hay, naked as a jaybird.
Yes, well, being naked in the hay can leave you picking straw out of your... oh, you probably mean the coming-to-kill me thing. No, no, that wasn't good.
You'd think so, but you'd be wrong. All I knew at the time was that sleeping in hay isn't as comfortable as you'd think, even with a gal on your arm.
Ha ha! Wait, m'<lord/lady>... it's about to get much worse than that.
So I am lying there with my big smile, aye? Suddenly, BAM! The door to the loft flies open, and there is the great vizier full of rage!
Oh, no. I'd already taken her virtue, and I wasn't aware of any honor, m'<lord/lady>. No, no, I hid behind her and screamed in terror like a banshee. Not the most heroic picture, I'll admit.
Fought him? With what, my dashing smile? I hid behind his daughter and screamed in terror like a banshee. Not the most heroic picture, I'll admit.
I darted through his legs and fled naked into the streets. Before I knew it, the vizier was chasing me through half the city, firing off lightning bolts and curses at a rapid pace.
My patroness was also a bit miffed to see us breeze past her, and she too took up the chase. Her fury grew and grew as we stayed ahead of her.

I ran for all I was worth, but bugger me if that wizard couldn't move those skinny little legs of his! The medusa finally found him throttling me angrily atop the largest building in the Market Sabaan.
Well, my patroness was mad enough that she was determined to be the one to murder me first. She and vizier yanked me between them like some tug-of-war, and all I could do was gurgle helplessly!
They shouted threats and screamed at each other until the medusa lifted her veil! The vizier saw this and launched himself at her, casting a deadly spell as he flew!
He hit her squarely and they both flew over the edge of the rooftop! I would have been gladly rid of them both, but alas poor Tomi was catapulted right along with them!

We hit three canopies on the way down and finally landed square in the middle of the market! The vizier's spell had worked, as the medusa was dead... but not before he had been turned into a statue. A broken statue, by that time. And there I sat, naked and stunned but otherwise unhurt.
Well, sure, m'<lord/lady>. The crowd assumed I had killed a powerful medusa and a famous wizard... bare-handed, no less. I was in no condition to argue.
Hmph. I wish! The entire crowd assumed I had killed a powerful medusa and wizard bare-handed... and I was in no condition to argue.
Word spread rapidly, of course... and the story grew. You wouldn't believe some versions I heard. Sadly, the constabulary believed them.
I was a wanted man for murdering the vizier. Good for my reputation, perhaps, but bad for my health. His daughter wasn't too impressed, either.
You'd think so, but no... she just didn't want to shack up with a wanted halfling. I had to prove my innocence!
Well, she didn't miss her father like I thought she would... she just wasn't about to marry a wanted halfling. I had to prove my innocence!
That's why I decided to come to Neverwinter. One of my oldest friends lives here and is a forgery master! I was hoping he'd make some documents to clear my name in Calimport.
Sadly, I suspect Belman's fallen victim to the plague. Can't find him anywhere. So... that means no evidence and no marriage for poor li'l Tomi.
Oh, who cares about him? I just want those documents. Maybe he finished them before he croaked. *Sigh* I can only hope.
Oh, I bet he is. Belman was never very lucky. I just hope he finished those documents before he croaked.
Oh, there's not much story left to tell, is there, m'<lord/lady>? I'm just hoping we'll come across Belman's documents someday.
That'd be nice of ya, m'<lord/lady>. Until then, let's just go about your quest, aye?
Fat chance of that, m'<lord/lady>. Let's get back to your quest, then, shall we?
Wha-aat? You're kidding, right? Let me see that! Hmmm... Hayden, Lord Friedling. 'Halfling'. Yep, that's my old monicker.
And it really is Belmar's work, after all. Just my luck that it would be his crappiest work ever! I'd be laughed out of Calimport if I tried to use this!
Ah, well, that's life. Saida had the biggest buck teeth, anyway... don't know what I was thinking. I suppose I should thank you for saving me the effort, m'<lord/lady>.
Hmmm... come to think of it, here. Let me give ya this in return. It was a ring that the vizier wore that I, um, managed to slip off his finger before he got stoned.
Yeah, well... the vizier seemed to value it. Said it had great magic in it, but it never did nothing for me. Maybe it'll bring you luck.
At any rate, I don't have to worry about finding stupid Belmar anymore. I would have had to kill him for being an idiot, anyway.
Let's just keep on with your quest, m'<lord/lady>, aye?
Naaahhh, I'm not in the mood to talk more about that. Let's just keep going with your quest, aye?
Well, there's only so much you can know about me, m'<lord/lady>. Tomi Undergallows be the most famous halfling rogue in all of Calimport... that about sums it up.
Oh, I've my tales of treachery and deceit, the likes of which have been told to wide-eyed little Calimshite children for many years... but I doubt you'd be interested in that.
Gee, let me think... what might have made me offer to tell a story? Oh, I know! You asked for it! Sheesh.
Have it your way, though, m'<lord/lady>. Might want to check for bunches in your panties before we're off.
Wow, you get little bossy when you want a story, aye? Well, all right, have it your way.
Well, let's see. Tomi's had a bunch of friends and a bunch of enemies in his time. There's only been one who's been both: my arch-nemesis, Samuel Bumbleheart!
Sammy and I were pals dating back to the good old days when we used to run wild through the streets as wee little urchins, stealing avacados and pinching purses.
Fame was always Sammy's thing. He's always loved attention, ever since he did that striptease in the half-orc bar to keep from being pummelled, I've always thought he was a bit of a diva.
When I started to gain a bit of notoriety of my own, however, Sammy become a mite jealous. Poor lad.
Mmmm... naw, not so much. It's a bit hard to pick a pocket when you have twenty suspicious eyes on you. Great with the lasses, though, I'll admit.
We used to be when we were tots, sure, but the plain fact is Sammy's not such a good rogue. So clumsy and wobbly, it's a shame to call him a halfling sometimes.
Sammy was content for awhile, but he'd get mad when folks always recognized me first. The guards would chase me down the street and he'd complain, "Why didn't they chase ME?"
Oh, he tried to show me up as a thief. Not being very good, however, it only landed him in prison. In Calimshan, that means you're as good as hung.
I busted him out the first time, but that only embarrassed him. No good deed goes unpunished, you know... so Sammy had to take action!
Well, the truth is I didn't really mean to break him out. It was an accident... the kind that brings down half the prison and causes a mass escape. Happens all the time, trust me.
So Sammy concocts this plan to have l'il Tomi thrown in prison... just like he'd been. He was going to steal the most fabulous gem in Calimshan and I was to take the blame for it!
Ahhhh, Sammy. Maybe he still resented my stealing both his lady friends. Hmm... actually, I stole his wife, too. Naaaah, that was years and years before.
I didn't say that Sammy was the smartest halfling on the block. In his mind, having me stuck in a Calimshite prison and ravaged daily by burly convict cell-mates was worth almost any price.
Well, with my reputation, who wouldn't believe him? For one of Sammy's plans, it was right brilliant. He was such an angry, angry little halfling.
Anyway, since Sammy wasn't so skilled, he had to get some help. Ended up leveraging himself to a rather nasty elf by the name of Reegar.

Reegar was good... he was also the meanest rogue in Calimshan, and Sammy had to practically become his servant to get him to agree. Reegar was also a pretty good pal of mine, though Sammy didn't know that.
Thing was, I'd already been planning to heist that jewel myself all along. When Reegar tipped me off to Sammy's plan, I laughed so hard I just about peed in my britches.
I don't know why Sammy was so mad, really. He just seemed to lose it completely... all that shouting and turning red in the face, it was just so sad.
After all, he'd only broken a couple of legs... he could still walk, even if it was with a limp. Could I be held completely to blame?
At any rate, Sammy decided enough was enough. It was time to ruin his best pal, Tomi, once and for all.
Of course I was! I mean... so what if I was the one who did the job he got arrested for? So what if I slept with his lady friend while he was in prison? We were buds!
And what better way to become famous than to take down the notorious Tomi Undergallows!
Sammy came up with a plan! Not the brightest plan, I suppose... he was never much of a planner.
His last plan, in fact, was a heist that ended up with him being left naked and cold on a ship to Maztica. Well... all right, I did forget to go pick him up... but it was HIS plan.
This plan would be different, however! Hee hee... or so he thought. I'll have to tell you about it sometime, m'<lord/lady>.
Right-o! I was telling you about Sammy's big plan to ruin ol' Tomi, wasn't I? Ahhhh, yes.
Aye, well, he was a fellow to pity, at times. Once I remember I left Sammy in the Dark Bazaar by accident. He showed up three days later, pitch-white and devoid of hair. Ha ha! Those were the days...
I did the only thing I could, of course. I made a plan of my own, and went ahead with the heist.
Until the night of the heist, I didn't let on that I knew what Sammy was up to. He acted all innocent, of course... didn't say a word to me, even told me to get lost.
It was quite a ruse, I tell you, but I saw through it all! He was no friend of mine, after all... he had become my arch-nemesis!
Dumb? What's so dumb about it? Friendship! Betrayal! It has all the classic elements I promised! The fact that I was the victim in all this is beside the point.
Wha-aat? Why would you think that? Well... there was that one time I told Rok the Crusher that Sammy stole his hammer, and not me, but Sammy forgave me after he healed, I swear!
Exactly! Like a cunning serpent, he had hidden himself as my friend! Never would I have suspected simple Sammy, the childhood pal I had de-pantsed in front of the Molikai girl's choir!
Still... I'd only wanted to teach Sammy a lesson. What happened to him the night of the heist was quite tragic.
Aye, it's terrible. The one thing I truly regret in my life...
Aye, laugh if you wish, m'<lord/lady>, but it's truly awful. The one thing I regret in my life...
Aye, it's hard to hear. Terrible. The one thing I truly regret in my life...
I shall have to tell you about it... sometime. *Sigh* Let's... let's just go on with your quest. I don't want to think about Sammy any longer.
Aye... the night of the jewel heist, right? *Sigh* I suppose you've been a fine friend, m'<lord/lady>. I can tell you about it.
The gem we were after was no other than the fabled 'Star of Calimshan'. It's not the most valuable ruby in the land, but certainly one of the more notorious.
According to legend, the pashas of Calimshan gifted it to their wives on their wedding night, and the stone glows from within... filled with the tears of their lost innocence. Or so the story goes.
My daring plan... and Sammy's... was to pluck this stone from the depths of the royal palace, from the very chambers of the syl-pasha's wife, herself.
The ruby's value is more in the fame one would get, m'<lord/lady>. The syl-pasha would never rest until he captured whoever was responsible fro its theft.
I wasn't actually sure. I was still getting used to the idea that Sammy had turned into my arch-nemesis for no reason at all.
Oh, aye. What would be far worse, however, would be the syl-pasha's reaction. Taking it would be one thing... surviving long enough to enjoy it would be something else.
At any rate, the night came. Sammy and Reegar stole into the palace ahead of me, with Sammy having no idea of my presence. Reegar left a trail that was quite easy to follow.
I remember being impressed at the time that things were going so well... no guards alerted, no problems whatsoever. I thought maybe Sammy's foul luck had finally turned, for once.

Well, of course Sammy tripped over a fold in the carpet and took a spill into a suit of armor. It fell over him into two others and the resulting clatter would have woken Nebuchadnezzar's dead brother-in-law.
Poor Reegar turned white as a virgin's dainty bottom when he saw the horde of soldiers charging down the hall. He leapt out the window without first considering we were over the lion pit. Poor fella.
The guards ran right past the pile of armor... didn't even think to look for a small halfling buried under there, lucky for Sammy.
Oh, I suppose. It's not as bad as that time we tried to rob the merchant guild and I knocked over that vat of alchemist's fire and torched all of Sammy's body hair off.
I am shocked and dismayed that you think that, m'<lord/lady>. Did Sammy deserve that time I accidentally sold him into slavery to the Altooshans? No, of course not!
Anyway... give ol' Sammy some credit for stubbornness, he climbed out from under that armor and still came for the ruby. Found me plucking it from its pedestal, in fact.
He was surprised to see me, to say the least. I decided to give him a piece of my mind, as I recall. "Why, Sammy," I said, "why did you betray me? I've never done anything to you!"
What do you mean? Oh, I admit... I made one or two mistakes in the past, but Sammy and I were pals! Not anymore, of course, now that Sammy'd turned traitor.
I never got to hear his response. Oddly, he just turned all purple and his eyes bulged out and he spluttered a lot. Looked rather like some outraged kobold.
The guards ran in just then and it was pandemonium. There was fighting and screaming and running... last I remember, I dived into the sea and woke up three days later on freighter bound for Tharsult.
Want to hear the funny part? For all that Sammy was a terrible thief, he was a wonderful pickpocket. Stole the ruby off me, he did, and I had nothing to show for all that.
Not sure, exactly. I'd heard he'd ended up on a slave ship and somehow got sold to one of the High Captains in Luskan. Poor sod.
Me, I'd like to track down that ruby one of these days. The Star of Calimshan... ahhh, it'd still be worth it, to make me famous.
Ha! There's not much more to it. One of these days, I'll find the Star of Calimshan. Maybe find out what happened to Sammy, too... I've decided to forgive him.
Thanks, m'<lord/lady>! You're quite a friend, yourself! Now let's get on with your quest, shall we?
Ain't that the truth! It takes a special kind of man to have that much forgiveness in his heart. I think Sammy will be pleased.
By Brandobaris's hairy feet! It is! Where in Faerun did you find that?
Huh. So Sammy did make it up hereabouts, after all. Probably slaved away in some wizard's kitchen until he slipped into a vat of ale and drowned. Ah, well.
Thanks for finding it, m'<lord/lady>... it'll take up a nice spot on my mantle. If I had a mantle, that is.
Wish I had something 'side from some pocket lint to pay ya back. All I can offer you is my thanks and friendship in return.
You have a point there, m'<lord/lady>. Now let's find your cultists and kick some zealot butt!
You're a good <man/woman>, m'<lord/lady>. Now let's find your cultists and kick some zealot butt!
Ahhh, no worries, m'<lord/lady>! We'll find your cultists, sure enough... Sammy can wait.
Nahhh, this isn't the time, m'<lord/lady>. We have cultists to find and cut into little cultist-sized bits, don't we?
Funny you should ask that, m'<lord/lady>. I was an urchin on the streets of Calimport, first an' foremost... and that's where I learned me street-smarts... but it wasn't always that way.
In fact, when I was a tender young lad a kindly human wizard saw great promise in me and took me in. I was his apprentice, in fact, for quite some time.
That's where I met my best friend Sammy, after all... he was another apprentice. I would have been a full wizard, myself, if things had worked out.
You're making fun of me, now, aren't you, m'<lord/lady>? Ha ha! It's true, though. When it came to books and studying, I may as well have been a Sahuagin in the desert.
Well, you know... you can take the lad out of the street, but you can't take the street out of the lad. I wasn't much for books and studying and all.
That wizard... what was his name? Halasahr? He saw something in me that I never saw. Said I would make a wizard whether I liked it or not.
I thought I would make a wonderful thief if I could be invisible and fly around all the time... I just couldn't wait! Halasahr had all these pretty things in his tower, unfortunately.
Now you sound just like him. Oh! And the beatings that man would apply! He wasn't the most patient sort himself, you know.
Well, you may think so, but ol' Halasahr was quite the taskmaster. One line mispronounced and I'd be black and blue for days! He should have been a fighter with that arm.
Of course I stole them! What kind of a rogue do you think I am? Got a good price on the streets, too, even Halasahr beat me black and blue by the time I returned.
Once I swiped Halasahr's spellbook and sold that for a pretty price. Boy, was the old man furious! There was a storm brewing around his tower by the time I got back!
Of course I had to lie and say that Sammy took the book. Hmmm... come to think of it, that's how Sammy got kicked out of his apprenticeship.
Well, he wasn't much of a wizard... and ol' Sammy wasn't my friend back then, anyway. I made it up to him by becoming his pal later, once I stopped being an apprentice.
Heh... the end of my apprenticeship is quite the story, itself. I should tell you that sometime, m'<lord/lady>, if you're interested.
That would be later, though. Right now we got a city to save, right?
Was I telling a story, m'<lord/lady>? Oh, right... about the end of my apprenticeship with Halasahr.
Well, wizards are a funny lot, you know. No self-respecting thief would go poking his nose into places where it's sure to get cut off, but wizards run like moths into bonfires.
Halasahr was no different. He didn't want me to find out, of course, but I had a way of sneaking around his tower without him knowing... and I saw him summoning demons.
Why does any wizard summon demons? Power, knowledge, succubus booty? Who can tell? Maybe he needed a chess partner.
Sure. Big, red, bat wings, bad breath, infernal contract. Shoot, that was in the opening paragraph of 'the Apprentice Essentials'. I am from Calimshan, you know.
I don't know about evil. We are talking about Calimshan, here. I knew of two noblemen alone who had a succubus doing their housecleaning.
Anyway, this demon seemed harmless enough. Halasahr and it had some laughs, and it tickled the mage's belly until he was giggling like a schoolgirl.
So after Halasahr dismissed it and left, I decided I would call up this demon and see just how much riches he could give me. It really didn't seem like such a big thing at the time.
Sheesh, you make it sound like we got married and ran off to the Dales to live in bliss. I only summoned it once, m'<lord/lady>, gosh.
Aren't they the ones that give you three wishes? After you rub their bellies or something? I never much paid attention to my studies, you know.
Of course I did! I mean... the bottle was just sitting there, looking all lonely. If Halesahr was a responsible wizard he would have locked it away. So I wasn't at fault for anything I did.
So I read a bit of the wizard's book and summon the demon, right? Well... the demon looks all surprised to see me and he just laughs and laughs and laughs.
I ask him what's so damn funny, right? He says, "Why you, little one!" He has this big, booming voice... and all I can think is 'boy, I am gonna be SO rich!'
Well, I shout at him and demand that he make me rich, right? And he laughs again. So I say he better make me powerful, then... figuring that's maybe just as good.
So he laughs again! Finally he calms down and he says okay and gives me a magic wand. Says that will give me all the power I need... and 'poof!' he's gone.
Boy, that wand got me into so much trouble...
Hey! I can handle my magic perfectly well! Well... usually. Well, okay, nevermind.
Why? It was all perfectly innocent. Who was I to look a gift horse in the mouth, after all?
Heh... I'll have to tell you what the wand did sometime later, maybe. Let's just say Halasahr wasn't happy about it.
Anyway... I'm sure we've more important things to do. Right, m'<lord/lady>?
Ahhhh, I guess there's no harm in it. It was such a big mess, though, m'<lord/lady>.
If you'll remember, the wee demon had given me a wand, aye? So after he left, I decided that it needed to be tested out.
Aye, exactly. It was exhilirating, m'<lord/lady>... the power at my disposal! I had my apprentice chores to do, and I decided the wand should do them for me!
I animated a broom to do my bidding, and it began to clean the floors! I used the wand to make a bucket that never ran short of water!
I made the tables walk, the cauldrons dance, the chairs four-step... it was marvelous! I waved my wand and everything came to life!
Oh, you think so, do you? When was the last time you summoned up a big demon who gave you a gift, huh? Happens all the time, does it?
Well, he wasn't around, naturally. Considering the source of the wand, I didn't exactly want to advertise it.
Well... the broom was the first problem. It began cleaning more than the floors. It started sweeping the shelves, knocking Halasahr's components about, breaking things. I couldn't make it stop!
In a panic, I hacked the broom apart with an axe... but then both halves became brooms! I kept hacking and hacking... and suddenly the room was filled with brooms! They were breaking everything!

In my haste, I knocked over the bucket... and suddenly the tower began filling up with water! The table was attacking me... I couldn't do anything! The tower was being destroyed! Chaos! Chaos! Oh, the humanity!
And then Halasahr came back...
Well, no... he didn't try to kill me. The way he looked down at me, all disappointed and angry... I thought I'd pee my britches.
No... no, he wasn't pleased. He looked down at me all mad and disappointed. He was so scary I thought I'd pee my britches.
He snatched the wand from me and he broke it... and that made all the madness stop. Oh, and he yelled and yelled at me... he practically threw me out of the tower and told me never to come back.
The bright news is, I hear Halasahr told some writer about it and the writer thought it was so amusing, he made a play! Think it will be a musical?
You know, I do feel a bit bad about the whole thing. Not for me... I knew I was no wizard. I feel bad for Halasahr. He did treat me pretty good, all things considered.
He had a bunch of rare components destroyed that night. Worst of all was these ashes... the ashes of a great warrior. They were for his longevity potion.
I've always thought I should try to make it up to him one day... find him those ashes, maybe. Unless he's gone and died of old age.
Well... I've been thinking about it. I'd really like to find those ashes sometime... the ashes of a warrior hero. I owe it to Halasahr, don't you think?
Either way, I figure I'll stick by your side so long as you're on your quest. You found me the documents and the ruby... maybe we'll find the ashes, too. Maybe it's meant to be.
Aye, who knows? Either way, I'm happy toodling along after you, m'<lord/lady>. Lead on!
Oh, keep your knickers on, already. I said I'd come along with ya, didn't I? Sheesh. Some people's children.
But you never know, do you? Heck... maybe I could even track my old friend Sammy down one day. Think he'd be happy to see me?
Well... now maybe they would, at that. Let me think. Aye... aye, I think that would serve for Halasahr's longevity potion just fine!
Thank you, m'<lord/lady>. Here... since you're such a friend, let me give you this. It's a powerful ring that I stole from Sammy way back. Maybe you could use it.
Well... it's the only thing I stole off Sammy that was valuable enough for me to keep. The rest of the stuff I got rid of long time ago. That should be worth something.
Aye, it's not a problem, m'<lord/lady>... least I could do. It's the only thing I stole off Sammy that was valuable enough for me to keep.
I'll send these ashes off to Halsahr as soon as I get the chance. Hmmm... I wonder if he'll still accept an apprentice at my age?
Sure! Why not? With some magic at hand, I could be the greatest thief that Calimport has ever known! Again! Ha ha!
Oh, why not? You don't think he'd still hold a grudge do you? I could learn from him and become the greatest thief Calimport has ever known! Again! Ha ha!
Oh, don't you worry your little head about it, m'<lord/lady>. I'm not leaving until your quest is good and done.
Let's get under way, then, my friend! We'll find your Words of Power and put an end to evil... for even more adventure awaits us afterwards, I'm sure of it!!
Maybe later, m'<lord/lady>. Right now we've got stuff that needs doing, don't we?

The toolset has found a temporary working directory for a module. It appears that the toolset did not properly close the last edited module, but there is no module information file to recover.

The common Badger is a small but fierce mammal. Intensely protective of their territory, they make good companions for Druids. Often, the Badger will become enraged and simply throw itself into battle without a second thought.
Badger Companion
Large and strong, Brown Bears are feared by many. Never to be underestimated for the unwary can lose a head beneath the claws of one of these powerful animals.
Brown Bear Companion
The Dire Boar is a larger, more vicious version of their common cousins. Their thick hide and bone ridges allow them to wade into battle without much of being hurt.
Dire Boar Companion
The Dire Wolf is feared by many but loved by few. For a creature of their size and power, they are surprising nimble.
Dire Wolf Companion
With their keen senses and quick movements, Hawks are efficient hunters. Many have even been trained to disarm foes.
Hawk Companion
Black as a Chultan night and just as deadly, these sleek cats attack from the shadows, disappearing back into them once the hunt is through.
Panther Companion
Giant Spider Companion
Wolves, always the pack hunter, will follow the Alpha male or female, be they Wolf, Human or Demi-Human.
Wolf Companion
Among the swiftest and most agile creatures in existence, Air Elementals are often summoned for use in great battles over vast stretches of open terrain.
Air Elemental
Even swifter and more agile than their lesser kin, these Air Elementals are among the oldest of their kind.
Elder Air Elemental
Greater Air Elemental
Huge Air Elemental
The spectral remains of people driven to madness and suicide, Allips crave only revenge against those who pushed them over the brink.
Allip
Intelligent, shapeshifting spiders with sorcerous powers, Aranea avoid physical combat, prefering to rely on their webs and spells instead.
Aranea
Azer
Natives of the Plane of Fire, these surly, flame-clad dwarves are nevertheless honorable and able warriors once provoked.
The common Badger is a small but fierce mammal. Its strong forelimbs are armed with long claws, used for both digging and self-defense.
Badger
Bandit
Bandit Archer
Bandit Rogue
Bandit Cleric
Bandit Mage
Half-Orc Bandit
Bandit Chief
Bartender
These winged, nocturnal rodents are rarely considered threatening in their own right, though traditional folklore does associate them with vampirism and the undead.
Bat
Battle Horrors are magically animated suits of empty armor. They have a greater array of magic powers than do their lesser kin, Helmed Horrors.
Battle Horror
Bred for use as spies and messengers in the Underdark, these former Intellect Devourers are virtually unkillable, though they no longer retain their psionic abilities.
Battle Devourer
A forest-dwelling omnivore, the common Black Bear is not aggressive by nature, though it can be very dangerous when protecting its cubs or food supply.
Black Bear
More aggressive and carnivorous than the smaller Black Bear, Brown Bears are commonly considered to be very bad-tempered and territorial.
Brown Bear
Dire Bears are larger, more vicious versions of their common cousins. They are often found in the company of powerful rangers or druids.
Dire Bear
Grizzly Bear
Their thick, white fur a product of their northern climate, these graceful and powerful hunters are a rarity, even in their natural habitat.
Polar Bear
Beast of Xvim
Hound of Xvim
Begger, Female
Beggar
An intelligent, predatory canine with limited teleportation abilities, Blink Dogs hunt in packs, 'blinking' randomly until they surround their prey.
Blink Dog
Though not true carnivores, these wild swine are very bad-tempered and usually charge anyone who disturbs them, ripping at them with their tusks.
Boar
Dire Boars are larger, more vicious versions of their common cousins. They are often found in the company of powerful ranger or druids.
Dire Boar
With their gray, hairless flesh and empty white gaze, Bodaks are the undead remains of those who have been destroyed by the touch of evil.
Bodak
Called such for their ability to lob balls of digestive acid over considerable distances, these giant beetles feed primarily on carrion and offal.
Bombardier Beetle
Recognizable by its distinctive red markings, the predatory Fire Beetle prefers its meals to be cooked, even a little burnt...
Fire Beetle
These creatures are serious pests that greedily devour cultivated crops. Though not carnivorous, they'll still charge any perceived threat with their oversized, horn-like mandibles.
Stag Beetle
As their name suggests, Stink Beetles defend themselves by emitting a noxious gas intended to render their assailants unconscious.
Stink Beetle
The biggest and strongest of the goblinoids, Bugbears receive their name from their bear-like noses, strong upper body, and keen sense of smell.
Bugbear
Bugbear Hero
Bugbear Shaman
Leopard
This flightless, domesticated bird is prized both for its tender meat and for the eggs it lays on an almost daily basis.
Chicken
These hound-headed angels are the resolute foot soldiers of the celestial army. They are often sent to defend the innocent and protect the weak.
Hound Archon
Hound Archon, Female
Often mistaken for more malevolent Will-o-Wisps, Lantern Archons are actually celestial beings. They are very friendly and usually eager to give what assistance they can.
Lantern Archon
Commoner, Female
Commoner, Male
Convict
A large and powerful wild cat, the Cougar makes its home in mountainous regions. It's often identified by its tawny, unmarked coat.
Cougar
Raised for both its hearty meat and nourishing milk, these large herbivores are a staple resident of rural barnyards.
Cow
The fabled 'Hunter-of-Men' is a sure-footed predator of the North. More than just a simple bobcat, however, it wields some magical properties as well.
These bear-headed heavenly creatures are fiercely independent, acting as self-appointed bounty hunters with the sole aim of bringing in the unrighteous for judgment.
Celestial Avenger
This magic ammunition has a bonus to damage, but it doesn't bear the hallmarks of any specific maker.
Cult Member
Curst
Curst Warrior
Curst Rogue
Curst Ranger
Curst Monk
Typically docile in nature, these wild, skittish herbivores gather in small groupings that scatter quickly when threatened.
Deer
White Stag
With their flaming wings and skull-like countenance, these demons are among the greatest and most feared of their kind.
Balor
Bred by Mind-Flayers in the deepest Underdark, these 'four-legged brains' stalk intelligent prey, co-opting their bodies after devouring their brain.
Intellect Devourer
Dire Badgers are larger, more vicious versions of their common cousins. They are often found in the company of powerful ranger or druids.
Dire Badger
Dire Tiger
Dire Wolves are larger, more vicious versions of their common cousins. They are often found in the company of powerful rangers or druids.
Cowardly but cunning, these small, demonic humanoids are often bound to the will of sorcerers and wizards and made to do their bidding.
Quasit
With perfect builds and flawless skin, Succubi are the most comely of demons. They live to tempt mortal men into crimes of passion.
Succubus
Bony, vulture-like creatures, Vrocks are the foot soldiers of the Abyss. Notoriously vain, they prance about in battle, admiring their sharp claws and beaks.
Vrock
Easily domesticated and trained, the common Dog has been a popular guard, hunting servant, and travelling companion for ages.
Dog
The cursed, undead corruptions of once-upright paladins who fell from grace, Doom Knights are the scourge of all lands over which they hold dominion.
Doom Knight
Black Dragons are evil-tempered, cunning, and malevolent. Especially fond of coins, they often question their humanoid prey about stockpiles of gold before killing them.
Adult Black Dragon
Old Black Dragon
Ancient Black Dragon
Blue Dragons are vain and territorial. They prefer to hunt on cloudless days, when their blue scales allow them to blend with the open skies.
Adult Blue Dragon
Old Blue Dragon
Ancient Blue Dragon
Brass Dragons are talkative gossipmongers. They may have useful information, but usually share it only after long rambling and hinting for a gift.
Adult Brass Dragon
Old Brass Dragon
Ancient Brass Dragon
Bronze Dragons are inquisitive and enjoy polymorphing into animals to better observe adventurers. Fascinated by warfare, they'll eagerly join a just cause... for good pay.
Adult Bronze Dragon
Old Bronze Dragon
Ancient Bronze Dragon
Copper Dragons are incorrigible pranksters, joke tellers, and riddlers. Most are good-natured but also have a covetous, miserly streak.
Adult Copper Dragon
Old Copper Dragon
Ancient Copper Dragon
Gold Dragons are graceful, sinuous, and wise. They hate injustice and foul play, often embarking on self-appointed quests to promote good.
Adult Gold Dragon
Old Gold Dragon
Ancient Gold Dragon
Green Dragons are belligerent and prone to attacking without provocation. They make their lairs in old growth forests where they fly beneath the canopy.
Adult Green Dragon
Old Green Dragon
Ancient Green Dragon
Red Dragons are the most covetous of all Dragons. Exceptionally vain, they are forever seeking ways of making other creatures pay them tribute.
Adult Red Dragon
Old Red Dragon
Ancient Red Dragon
Silver Dragons are regal and statuesque. They cheerfully assist good creatures in genuine need, often taking human or elven form to maintain their anonymity.
Adult Silver Dragon
Old Silver Dragon
Ancient Silver Dragon
Among the smallest and least intelligent of Dragonkind, most White Dragons are simply animalistic predators with a predilection for gems and frozen meat.
Adult White Dragon
Old White Dragon
Ancient White Dragon

Drow Militia
Drow Mage
Drow Assassin
Dryads are exquisitely beautiful tree sprites found deep in secluded woodlands. They sometimes aid adventurers and can prove a source of useful information.
Dryad
Duergar
Duergar Cleric
Duergar Warrior
Duergar Mage
Duergar Rogue

Earth Elementals are immensely strong and tough, capable of pounding almost anything into rubble. They are often summoned by armies laying siege to great cities.
Earth Elemental
Even stronger and tougher than their lesser kin, these Earth Elementals are among the oldest of their kind.
Elder Earth Elemental
Greater Earth Elemental
Huge Earth Elemental
Elf Mage
Elf Mercenary
Elf Ranger
Although not very intelligent, Ettercaps are cunning predators. Like the monstrous spiders that they keep as pets, they are skilled hunters and trappers.
Ettercap
Ettins, or two-headed giants, are vicious and unpredictable hunters that stalk the night. Their two heads make them exceptionally sharp-eyed and alert.
Ettin
Girl
Fenhounds serve as avenging spirits and guardians of the darkest moors and bogs. They draw their power from the mists of the places they protect.
Fenhound
Fire Elementals are fast and agile. The merest touch from their fiery bodies is sufficient to set many materials aflame.
Fire Elemental
Even faster and more agile than their lesser kin, these Fire Elementals are among the oldest of their kind.
Elder Fire Elemental
Greater Fire Elemental
Huge Fire Elemental
These winged, nocturnal rodents are quick, stealthy and very good at finding that that is hidden. They also seem to paralyse some with fear.
Bat Familiar
The fabled 'Hunter-of-Men', the Crag Cat is a sure-footed, intelligent, and tough predator. It is excellent at finding those that would hurt its master.
Panther Familiar
Pulled from the Elemental Planes, Mephits are cunning and swift opponents. These small creatures can be quite hard to kill and also quite deadly.
Fire Mephit Familiar
Hell Hounds are aggressive, fire-breathing canines brought to the Prime Material plane from the depths of the Abyss. Always a danger to be around, but they are loyal to their masters.
Hell Hound Familiar
Ice Mephit Familiar
Small but insidious devils often bound to the service of sorcerers and wizards, Imps have a gleeful attraction to pranks, riddles, and bawdy jokes.
Imp Familiar
These good-natured fey resemble tiny elves with long, gossamer wings. Being so small and highly intelligent, they often make very good scouts or thieves.
Pixie Familiar
Ravens are not considered the most beautiful of birds, but they can be taught to be useful. Although, they do not need to be taught how to tease, that is bred in their blood.
Raven Familiar
Gargoyles are vicious predators that enjoy torturing weaker creatures. Their ability to perch indefinitely without moving causes adventurers to frequently mistake them for statues.
Gargoyle
More deadly and cunning than their lesser kin, the Ghoul, these undead carrion eaters have the added ability to paralyze their victims.
Ghast
These undead carrion eaters haunt the graveyards and battlefields that bore them, still bearing the rotting flesh they once wore in life.
Ghoul
Corrupt officials are often said to become Ghoul Lords in their unlife. Cunning and intelligent, they often maintain a retinue of undead servants.
Ghoul Lord
Brutal and ruthless, Fire Giants resemble huge, dark-skinned dwarves. Well-organized and militaristic, they are typically encountered as well-armed phalanxes or twinned patrols.

Frost giants are justifiably feared as brutal and wantonly destructive raiders. They have the appearance of oversized, muscular humans with snow-white or ivory skin.
Frost Giant
Hunters and raiders with a selfish streak, Hill Giants seldom wash or repair their garments, preferring to add hides when their old ones wear out.

These brutish cave dwellers live communally and some have a basic grasp of magic. Intensely protective of their kin, they are generally reluctant to trust outsiders.

Created by demented wizards, Bone Golems are generally used to guard prized possessions. Their bodies are pieced together from various creatures, both humanoid and monster.

Unable to speak or make any vocal noise, these kilned and crafted horrors walk and move with a slow, clumsy gait.

While not true undead, these ghoulish constructs are crafted from collections of stolen human body parts, stitched together into single composite form.

Forged from solid iron, the crafting of these mighty juggernauts often requires the expertise and master craftwork of either dwarven blacksmiths or gnome artificers.
Iron Golem
Carved and etched with arcane symbols, Stone Golems are formidable opponents. Not only are they physically powerful, they are also very difficult to harm.
Stone Golem

These good-natured fey resemble tiny elves with long, gossamer wings. They despise evil creatures, and will attack them relentlessly if the opportunity arises.

The most common of the lycanthropes, Werewolves are also the most complex, socially. While some lead solitary existences, others form complicated ritual-bound societies.
Werewolf
These dark undead seek to destroy all life, filling graveyards with their victims and populating the world with their horrid progeny.
Wight
Evil creatures that feed on the powerful emotions associated with panic, horror, and death, Will-O'-Wisps delight in luring travelers into deadly peril.
Will-O'-Wisp
An icon of rugged individualism, yet renowned for its ability to hunt in packs, the noble Wolf is an animal of both mystique and power.
Wolf
Dangerous predators of the northern reaches, winter wolves pursue their prey relentlessly. Their breath is said to be cold enough to shatter stones.
Winter Wolf
Worgs are powerful wolves with an evil disposition and an uncanny intelligence. They are sometimes found with goblins, whom they serve as mounts and guardians.
Worg
Wraiths are incorporeal creatures born of evil and darkness. They despise all living things, as well as the light that nurtures them.
Wraith
Yuan-ti
Yuan-Ti Sorcerer
Yuan-Ti Priest
Corpses reanimated through necromancy, Zombies are mindless undead that shamble about, trying to satiate the dull ache of hunger in their decaying gut.
Zombie
The remains of priests and worshipers of evil deities, the rotting corpses of these Zombies exude a sickening green fog.
Tyrantfog Zombie

Many-Starred Cloak

These masterfully crafted cloaks, stitched on both sides with glittering stars, are the guild emblem of the sorcerers and wizards of Neverwinter's fabled Cloaktower. Loyal to Lord Nasher, the Cloakwizards are vital to the city's defense and carry themselves with the appropriately cautious air that such a duty entails.
Pot Helmet
Spike Helmet
Winged Helmet
Horse Hair Helmet
Stag Helmet
Watchman's Helm

It is unclear if these magic headpieces were created by clerics of Helm, god of guardians, or if they acquired their name by a more convenient circumstance. Whatever the case, they are highly prized by guards and sentries. All cast a visible glow of one sort or another, and many magically hone the wearer's senses. Needless to say, rogues have also taken to wearing them, proving the old proverb that 'what's good for the goose is good for the gander.'
Thieves' Hood

Bards and rogues alike are known to reminisce on "the glory days," and the stories of an ancient guild so magnificent it outfitted even its lowliest members with the most incredibly wondrous wares. Though there is little contained in historical documents to verify such a golden age, the occasional discovery of one of these Thieves' Hoods is enough to keep the tale in circulation.
Shukenja Helm

The Shukenja are a monastic order known for their subtlety and magic power. Though rank-and-file brothers fight with a staff and wear no armor, elite members of the order are known to wear Shukenja Helms into battle to augment their sorcerous abilities. Over the years these monks have spread through the Realms, and today many of their helms can be found in the hands of the order's allies and enemies.
Thayvian Circlet

Thayvian Circlets were created by the Red Wizards to help them fend off the aggressive Luskan Brotherhood. Though designed only to augment spellcasting abilities, they have the additional benefit of improving the wearer's hardiness, reflexes, and willpower. Since their introduction, the conflict between the two groups has been markedly restrained.
Golden Circlet

Creatures that attack the mind are the stuff of nightmares, so it is not surprising that items protecting against them might acquire some of their disrepute. Golden Circlets, for example, have been linked to a claim that when the drow first retreated underground they fed on intellect devourers, and that eating such a creature without wearing a circlet produced a mind flayer. This is all, of course, nothing more than superstitious tavern talk.
Large Shield +1
This magic shield grants additional protection to its wearer, but it doesn't bear the hallmarks of any specific maker.
Shield of the Holy

These shields are first mentioned in ancient liturgies of Lathander, in which the Morninglord's champions bear radiant shields against an infestation of undead. The shields made their first appearance in modern times in dramatic fashion, appearing miraculously at the altars of several of the deity's temples in the Year of Smoldering Spells, 1020 DR. Since that time a number have been lost in battle, and not a few were stolen by foul creatures to prevent their use.
Shield of the Sun

Forged by clerics of the Mulhorandi sun god Horus-Re, these shields are constantly aglow with the golden fires of the sun. Depending on the skill and intent of the crafter, some Shields of the Sun carry more potent powers as well.
Mirror Shield

Often confused with the better-known Shield of Mirrors, which has been known to aid in the defeat of medusas and basilisks, Mirror Shields are most often seen on the arms of mage hunters. Aside from their silvered appearance, Mirror Shields are so named because they can reflect harmful spells cast against their wielder.
Dragon Shield

Evil dragons are fearful opponents, but luckily for the good races of the world every dragon carries the seeds of its own destruction. When a single dragon falls, its scales are turned into shields and armor sovereign against its own attacks. A gifted artificer can even combine scales from different dragon types to produce items that resist many forms of elemental attack. The famed Dragon Shields are of this sort, and are among the best equipment an ambitious dragonslayer can carry.
Uthgardt Holy Shield

The Uthgardt value strength above all, and these shields provide strength to spare. They also disdain fancy talk and fine words, and the shields do their best to make the wearer as barbaric as the wild men of the north.
Large Shield +2
Large Shield +3
Small Shield +1
Protector

This small shield proudly bears the mark of Luiren, homeland of the strongheart halflings. While few people think of halflings as possessing any real military tradition, the Luiren folk maintain well-organized militias led by the local clergy and supported with powerful divine magic. This shield likely belonged to an ordinary Luiren soldier who fell in defense of his homeland.
Hearth Shield
These famous shields, crafted by the dwarves of the Western Heartlands, are so called because they make even the fiercest blast of heat seem as comfortable and tolerable as a cozy hearth.
Dwarven Mirth

Among the dwarven people, the father of all bards was the Master Talesmith Simeron Steelhammer. Well-versed in his people's history and lore, he traveled extensively, spreading tales of their culture and achievements. Near the end of his long life, he returned one last time to his home in the Great Rift. From every lintel hung a version of this shield, commissioned by his clansmen to commemorate his homecoming.
Shield of the Wisp Hunter

Soggy Nurkel, legendary hero of the gnomes, is said to have lost himself while chasing swampland toads as a child. As the night fog settled in, will-o'-wisps lured him this way and that through the dark swamp. Outsmarting them, however, he wove a magic shield from the marsh reeds, crushing them with it as he sneaked up on them through the mists. Replicas are made every ten-year as part of the festivities celebrating his life.
Mithral Shield

This small shield is crafted from strips of mithral pounded so thin they are nearly transparent. Despite its light construction, it provides substantial protection to the wearer and renders him immune to spells that limit his movement.
Small Shield +2
Small Shield +3
Tower Shield +1
Imaskari Shield

Often mistaken for relics of the ancient Imaskari civilization, these massive shields were actually used against them by their enemies. While large and unwieldy, they offered substantial protection against the spells of the mighty wizards of Imaskar. Those still in use today continue to be a thorn in the side of spellcasters throughout Faerun.
Shield of the Dragonslayer

Like many items designed to defeat dragons, these shields can be traced to the year of the Dracorage (1018 DR). They were built with immensely strong materials and techniques, and rumors put a castle engineer in charge of their construction. There may be some truth in this rumor, since the shields resemble reinforced castle gates more than ordinary armor plates.
Goblin Shield of Nulbish

Nulbish, a half-orc ranger, became a champion of the northern orc clans during their fateful Goblin Wars. Despite his half-human heritage, they appreciated his ferocity in battle and the rousing speeches he gave from atop his piled victims. When Nulbish was killed by a member of his father's own clan, the orcs squabbled for months over who should bear his shield. Numerous forgeries were crafted during this time and the fragile orc alliance eventually splintered.
Hastsezini's Shield

A legendary mercenary of Riativin, Hastsezini urged the city's five competing wizards to pool their valuables in a single storehouse where he could stand guard over them all. Such was the respect and fear he commanded that all agreed and not a single theft was ever attempted on his watch. Hastsezini showed no interest in the riches he guarded, perhaps because each of the five wizards was content to pay him a full wage.
Darksteel Tower Shield

For a brief period in its history, Darksteel Tower was ruled by a vicious coven of surface-roaming drow. From shadowed alcoves, high priestesses stood guard over the tower by night and day, wrapping their sensitive skin in swaths of black cotton. When Harpers finally destroyed the nest, these huge and ominous shields were all that survived of Darksteel Tower. Neither the blades nor magic of the Harpers could dent them.
Tower Shield +2

It appears to prove that Mr. Freidling worked as a coachman in Murann for the entire duration of the previous year... and so couldn't possibly have been present in the city of Calimport for an unmentioned crime.
