The origin of the crystal is not clear, though Ortius was known to have bartered his services to planar creatures on occasion.
Discord
<Delete>Discord
Bastard Sword +2
Bastard Sword +3
Dagger +1

Courtesan assassins were famous for using their wit and charm to infiltrate the intimate chambers of the enemy by the most disarming method imaginable: they were invited. The practice became infamous, which is likely why it is used so infrequently today.
Courtesan Blade

Weapons of this type are technically impossible, since their blades are made of nothing but razor-sharp ice crystals. Most sages agree they are kept frozen by some sort of link to the inner planes, but this is ultimately just speculation. Ice Talon daggers show a jagged blade and may have been part of a single larger weapon at one time, though the force required to shatter the magic blade must have been enormous indeed.
Ice Talon

This weapon is thoroughly evil, a quality undiminished by the number of duplicates that have been found in the past. It pulses with a sickening energy, and its moist and yielding grip seems almost alive in the hand. All of this adds to the discomforting thought that it may have been grown, not forged. There is no indication what the source of these items might be.
Leech

Tagget Coldspring was a smith and tinker who specialized in automated guardians. He did a brisk business in the rich southern lands of Amn, earning the praise of nobles and government institutions for his low-maintenance fortifications. His masterpiece was a griffin-shaped golem with talons that held their edge no matter what they struck. It was eventually recycled, the individual blades sold to finance a new creation.
Tagget's Talon

Necromancers have very little tolerance for jokes at their expense, so the reaction of Lord Agorn Deathknell to a precariously perched bucket of chum above his laboratory door was entirely predictable, as was the death of the pixie responsible. The surprising part, especially to Argon, was the retaliation of dozens of outraged fey folk, who never suffer a poor sport. A number of their blades were recovered from Agorn's carcass.
Pixie Lance
Dagger +2
Dagger +3
Greatsword +1

All gemswords feature a prismatic blade that is fractured throughout, but still magically maintains its shape. Tales speak of a great crystal from which these weapons can be split, but the plane-traveling souls who relate these stories are often suffering from dementia, having lost their faculties while navigating dimensional barriers.
Gemsword

Like all greatswords from the Land of Berserkers, these weapons are massively built, and so durable that some have survived for thousands of years. These swords are notable for their effectiveness against spellcasters, and history records that the land's Witch rulers expelled all known copies out of fear of their abilities.
Blade of the Rashemi

The Church of Lathander is a wealthy institution, and makes no secret of its affinity for adventurers. In their eyes, these people dare to bring light to the forgotten and secret places, and therefore they will always find safe haven in a house of the Morninglord. On occasion the church will grant a boon to a particularly favorable person, a weapon that will serve to light the dark paths ahead.
Shining Light of Lathander

Forged by deep gnome craftsmen of the Underdark, blades of this sort were thought lost until a specimen was recently seen in the company of Finihan's Raiders, a group of casual adventurers. That sword, Vermin's Bane, traveled widely as a result, and was last reported as having been stolen in a caravan raid north of Luskan.
Vermin's Bane

This suit bears the mark of the dwarf Marrok, Master Blacksmith of Neverwinter's Shining Knight Arms and Armor. He forged it early in 1373 DR, to aid the heroes who sought to free his quarantined city from the virulent grasp of the so-called Wailing Death.
Harbinger Kin +1

This suit bears the mark of the dwarf Barun, a Master Blacksmith who worked from a makeshift forge in the Uthgardt village of Beorunna's Well. He forged it late in 1373 DR, to aid the war effort against Lady Aribeth the Betrayer, who was then marching against the northern city of Neverwinter and the Lords' Alliance.
Harbinger Kin +3
Greatsword +2
Greatsword +3
Katana +1

"...in the night there came the rain of fire, which crashed as though an avalanche of stone. There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapons to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though these blades are the supposed outcome.
<Delete>Celestial Fury

"...in the night there came the rain of fire, which crashed as though an avalanche of stone. There were craters in the square, and inside were the stars, from which we forged our vengeance and took back the land of our fathers." The writings of Kaa Mihnd, explaining how a poor fishing village could possess the weapons to challenge their wealthy overlord. The account has never been verified, though these blades are the supposed outcome.
Divine Fury

If memory serves correctly, these weapons date to the stadium battles of old Kai Chen province, where promising warriors would test their skills against the greatest samurai of the day in ritual combat. If ever a challenger was victorious, he or she won the people's ovation and fame forever, symbolized by a Kaga-To katana. The blade is etched with a simple phrase: "Tell me how you fight, and I will tell you what you are."
Kaga-To

Once thought a unique instance of the swordmaker's craft, several katanas of this type have now been linked to a ship that ran aground on the Sword Coast some years ago. All bear the markings of Master Hu Li, a great artificer from the east, but little else is known of him.
Master Li's Way

Besieged by a powerful wu-jen, Lord Sunang of Kara-Tur was forced into some very expensive alliances. Weapons like these were plentiful, but not cheap, and the strain of equipping his army against an ever-strengthening foe eroded his influence. In the end, Sunang's lands fell to their own weakness, not the swords of his enemy. Merchants may have supplied both sides with these same arms to extend their profits, but three centuries have hidden the answers.
Blade of the Elements
Sword Saint Legacy +1
Sword Saint Legacy +4
Katana +2
Katana +3
Longsword +1

A Soulrazor Minion is a shadow of the Soulrazor sword, duplicated with meticulous effort by Khol of Zhentil Keep. While unable to name the evil force behind the original blade, Khol found he could encourage it to infest other weapons in a process he called "bleeding the void." He created a number of Minions but apparently upset some greater balance, and was drawn through to whatever dark place it was that he had tapped.
<Delete>Blackrazor Minion

A Soulrazor Minion is a shadow of the original Soulrazor sword, duplicated with meticulous effort by Khol of Zhentil Keep. Soulrazor possessed seemingly limitless evil, corrupting all that dared wield it. While unable to name the force behind the first blade, Khol found he could encourage it to infest other weapons in a process he called "bleeding the void." He created a number of Minions but apparently upset some greater balance, and was drawn through to whatever dark place it was that he had tapped.
Soulrazor Minion

Blades of this type hail from the workshop of Raegik Hammerhold, a Rashemar smith who refused to reveal the secrets of his craft to any but his chosen apprentice. It is unknown how many Angurvadal blades may exist, but it is certain there are no more being produced. Raegik discovered his student dealing with the Red Wizards of Thay, and is believed to have died in the ensuing battle.
Angurvadal (Flame Tongue)

A legacy blade, this Blessing of the Daystar is one of several recovered from the Sons of Light, a group of knights who fought in the latter days of the Weeping War, 713 DR. Their leader, Scottie Torilson, was possessed of the one true Daystar, and through it they received the blessing of Torm in their last hour. They went to their deaths for a strategically unimportant elven village, because duty demanded nothing less.
Blessing of the Daystar

A series of these weapons were constructed for the defense of the library fortress of Candlekeep some 200 years ago. The keep had acquired a tome detailing the imprisonment of the pit fiend Aegatohl, and a score of malevolent creatures came to claim it. A small horde was held at bay by the Knights of the Mailed Fist, along with the unexpected assistance of Devon's Privateers, a group of pirates. The tome was later destroyed.
Cold Iron Blade
Astral Blade +1
Longsword +2
Astral Blade +2
Longsword +3
Rapier +1

Black Rider Quills take their name from a celebrated epic repeated in any bardic college worth its salt. The subject of the tale is dark, encouraging one to "dance around in your bones," but it is referenced here solely to stimulate the muse. These blades were likely forged in tribute, and were probably not present for the events of the original story. It is not known if they were commissioned together or individually.
<Delete>Black Rider Quill
Black Rider Quill

A series of runes claim these blades are designed for the "quick eradication of evil, that they will suffer no longer as creatures at odds with all that is good." A sweeping proclamation, one that suggests the involvement of a radical group no longer giving second thought to deadly force where villains are concerned. Certainly an unpopular stance in some quarters, though probably welcomed in others.
Mercykiller Blade

In recent years, a number of thieves' guilds reported losing members to these blades, the weapons left as gruesome signatures impaled in the victims' chests. The craftsman behind them was unknown, but the intent of the group using them was clear enough: to destabilize existing groups to facilitate their own expansion. It has been some time since the last killing, however, suggesting that the incursion was either abandoned or succeeded through less violent means. Members of the underground community have not been forthcoming with information.
Bleederkin

Bandits who prey on honest travelers have need of weapons that are light and easily concealed - weapons such as this one. It is certain that, whatever its origin, this deadly rapier was not meant for honest purposes. Merely holding it in the hand produces a larcenous gleam in the eye, and thoughts of fat merchants with fatter purses spring to mind unbidden. This weapon is a boon for thieves and a bane of honest men.
Rapier of the High Road
Namarra (Neversleep) +1
Namarra (Neversleep) +2
Rapier +2
Rapier +3
Scimitar +1

This magic scimitar bears the mark of Taka Kobe, an honored swordsmith of Kara-Tur whose work has been traveling the world in the hands of adventurers for quite some time now. Perfectly balanced, all of his blades are masterful examples of the swordmaker's craft, and are highly prized by collectors and combatants alike.
<Delete>Scimitar of Speed

Known blades of this configuration are traceable to the armory of Daavid Ali Fazeer, a merchant of renown 50 years ago. He claimed to have acquired these weapons aboard a drifting ghost ship, a vessel that sank soon after he found it, though he refused to state whether its crew achieved their ghost status before or after he arrived on the scene.
Shimmering Blade

This magic scimitar bears the mark of Taka Kobe, an honored swordsmith of Kara-Tur whose work has traveled the world in the hands of adventurers for quite some time now. Each of his blades is a masterful, perfectly balanced creation, and they are highly prized by collectors and combatants alike.
Scimitar of Speed

It is doubtful the victim of a Laughing Blade finds anything humorous about it. These items were created by master illusionist Daniel Suther, who wanted an interesting twist in the hedge maze he built. Several automatons were equipped with the weapons and heroes accepting his challenge had to battle them, the maze, and their own senses. Suther was eventually jailed after several deaths on his estate.
Laughing Blade

When the smithy guild of Endrab refused to admit Ula on the basis of her gender, she challenged their best weaponsmith to a contest to see who could forge the finer sword. She toiled for weeks, her workshop busy day and night, until she produced a flawless, beautiful scimitar. Enraged that a 'mere' woman should best him, the guildsman hired assassins to do away with her. Ula's story has since inspired many more women to take up her profession, and make many copies of Ula's famous blade.
Ula's Heart
Desert Wind +1

This weapon bears the mark of the dwarf Barun, a Master Blacksmith who worked from a makeshift forge in the Uthgardt village of Beorunna's Well. He forged it late in 1373 DR, to aid the war effort against Lady Aribeth the Betrayer, who was then marching against the northern city of Neverwinter and the Lords' Alliance.
Desert Wind +2
Scimitar +2
Scimitar +3
Short Sword +1

A rogue's dream, these weapons were commissioned by the Shadow Thieves to bolster their fledgling guild chapter in Baldur's Gate. Seen as a threat to local interests, they now face stiff resistance from the existing thieves' guild and law enforcement for the city, the Flaming Fist. Deaths have occurred, so a few of these items are beginning to surface on the black market.
Short Sword of Quickness

Spellcasters facilitate research by bartering magic, and though the practice does not usually span across planes, some resources just cannot be had locally. Such is the case for Ichthia, a sorceress currently peddling finely crafted implements of death. Though never seen, the cost of her shadowy aid is well known: she barters in souls, usually with people not aware of their worth. The original owners of a Neck-Knife are often dead on the inside themselves.
Ichthia's Neck-Knife

Swords of this type are boldly marked and clearly come from a single source, though the significance of that source remains hidden as yet. Known owners have not volunteered any revealing information, or even the cost they paid to acquire their weapons, if there was a cost other than a dangerous dungeon retrieval.
Breath of the Maiden

This is a swashbuckler's blade that has seen endless use in grand fights against "big nasties" sent forth by whomever. The Lucky Ones mercenary company commissioned these blades while still flush from their last big score. After their windfall they only adventured for the thrill of it, challenging each other to ever-greater feats of daring-do. Why are these weapons no longer with them? Sometimes the "big nasty" wins.
The Lucky One
Feyduster +1
Short Sword +2
Feyduster +2
This magic weapon has an enhancement bonus to attack and damage, but it doesn't bear the hallmarks of any specific maker.
Short Sword +3
Throwing Axe +1

These axes are so named because each strikes with a blast of thunder, often dazing or deafening the target. Though legend holds that the axes were a gift from the heavens themselves, they are too variable in power to have come from a single source. Most scholars agree that they were likely fashioned by several different artisans, perhaps in tribute to a lost original.
Thunderbeast Axe

The pride of the Thunderkind Corps until their dissolution in 1095 DR, these axes have seen battle countless times. Unfortunately, any individual acts of heroism accomplished with these weapons have been forgotten, forever overshadowed by a more dubious honor. Hangard's Axe is the only one of the lot individually remembered, losing its original name after a dwarf fond of ale made it famous by continually burying it in the foreheads of his friends.
Axe of the Coming Storm

These weapons supposedly came from a group of druids and rangers who appealed to Mielikki for aid in the defense of their wood. In answer, a flock of ravens descended, each transforming into a throwing axe capable of striking fear into the heart of its target. As with many such tales, the name of the group and even the location of the forest change with every teller.
Black Raven Axe

These items are vexing to modern sages, since their dwarven creator remains completely unknown. No dwarf yet encountered has claimed kinship with the mysterious smith, and further investigations are met with gruff explanations and eventually stony silence.
Rifthome Axe
These glowing red axes explode in flames when they strike their target. Like many such items, they are viewed by druids and rangers with suspicion, and by treants with open hostility.
Fire Axe
Throwing Axe +2
Throwing Axe +3
Dart +1
Dart of Stunning
Darts of this type can stun their targets, though potency and duration are determined by the power of the dart's creator.
Asp's Nest

Asp's Nest darts are vicious, their tips covered by a neatly arranged collection of fangs that deliver venom as effectively as snake's fang. These weapons may have originated with the beast tribes of the north, but their use has spread in recent times.
Ice Dart
Ice Darts give off a blast of frigid cold when they strike their target, flash-freezing armor and flesh alike.
Acid Dart
These darts have a stinging, indescribable odor about them. There also seems to be a faint hissing sound coming from their tips.
Dart of Accuracy
These precisely milled darts are balanced as well as the finest arrow, and seem to unerringly seek out their targets.
Dart +2
Dart +3
Shuriken +1
Stars of Ojy-do

Ojy was the spiritual guide for the village of Golden, but found himself pressed into work as a smith when bandits laid siege to the community. He fashioned these and other weapons so the defenders could fight back, and though he was unskilled in metalworking, he offered thanks to his guiding spirits for each successful hit of his hammer. That these stars still exist is a testament to the strength of his faith.
Dragon's Tail

Each weapon of this type bears the following inscription: "As the tail of the Dragon sweeps across the sky, so too will these stars be unerring and true, if no other intent is meant or suffered." Of course, this ungainly text is actually the poor translation of a single elegant symbol. Is it any wonder that the creator of the item remains unknown, when such lengths must be taken to understand so small a thing?
Shining Light

Years ago, Vilaneux of the Iron Order was lost to a hurricane and stranded in then-unknown Kara Tur. He and his full plate armor were an oddity to locals, but he soon proved his commitment to justice. He became so respected that, when he died, his armor was cut into these Shining Light weapons in tribute.
Many Talons

"The Calling" was an evil that infested the Azaki assassins' guild of Kara-Tur some 200 years ago. It corrupted a minor attendant, and elevated his family in exchange for gruesome service. The attendant's body eventually played host to the creature's soul, and in the chaos that followed it generated dozens of these weapons, apparently at will, before falling to an unknown sohei.
Grains of Sand

These are from the armory of Miri Shokiro, a warrior whose legacy is largely lost to history. What survives is the philosophy that defined her existence: "Be the sand, and nothing but time will take you. The rocks must become it, the waves and wind must bear it, and those who would hold it find it slips through their grasp. Always some trace in a faraway nook, if never the whole is seen again."
Shuriken +2
Shuriken +3

Docked Drow Boat
Debris
Someone has arranged these skulls into a pile.
Skeleton Bones
With the face turned down, it's hard to determine if the victim was male or female.
Zombie corpse
A portal glows softly before you. You wonder where it leads.
Recall Portal
This hunched creature is fashioned from dark stone. From the corner of your eye it almost seems to move, but when you turn to face it, all is still.
Statue
The sarcophagus' heavy lid is fashioned from unadorned stone.
Coffin
A sickly sweet smell emanates from the bubbling flasks and vials on this table. It appears to be the work of some form of alchemy.
A small altar rests before you. Age-old bloodstains have seeped into the stone, mingling with scorchmarks left from a long-extinguished fire.
Altar
A small altar rests before you. You catch your reflection in its polished gleam, feeling somehow at peace within its presence.
A small altar rests before you. The heavy stone seems stoic and firmly rooted, leaving you wondering how long it has been there.
The iron bars on this cage seem sturdy and well-fashioned. It would be a hard task to break them.
Cage
This sturdy blacksmith's anvil bears the dented sheen of long use. Something in you wonders what great weapons and armor have been shaped upon its well-worn surface.
The wicker bulls-eye of this archery target bears a fresh coat of paint.
The smell of mothballs has long since seeped into the wood of this armoire.
Armoire
Two arrows pierce the dead man's back.
Arrow-filled corpse
A heavy javelin sits in its groove, notched against the ballista's taut-drawn wire. You can imagine how a well-aimed shot might have the power to fell a dragon from the sky.
The remains of this ballista lay abandoned on the battlefield.
Wrecked Ballista
Thick metal bands encircle the barrel-planks, ensuring a tight seal.
The bedding is clean and soft, with feather pillows and a soft down comforter pulled over the sheets.
The sleeping mat is thin but does offer some measure of protection from the cold ground beneath it.
Bed Roll
The stout planks of this bench have been worn smooth by years of use.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
Merchants Shingle
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A slight breeze ripples the water's surface, giving your reflection a life of its own.
The gilded bars curl around each other gracefully, conjuring up sensations of jasmine-scented evenings, cool breezes, and the songs of a nightingale.
Bird Cage
A pool of blood leaves its mark upon this place.
Silks from far east, light cottons from across the sea, hand-spun wool from local herds, all of them jumbled together like close neighbors in a foreign land.
The books lay piled atop each other with little in the way of rhyme or reason, as if someone was interrupted while in the process of returning them to their place.
A dizzying array of written works, each catalogued according to some fashion you cannot fathom. A number of them appear to be written in foreign tongues altogether.
Bookshelf
Loosely nailed, this wooden crate appears intended for temporary storage.
Crate
The brazier gives off a hot glow. As you reach toward it, you can feel beads of sweat forming on the palm of your hand.
Sap still leaks from the rough-hewn tip of this battering ram. It appears to have been recently fashioned.
One of the axles has snapped, rendering this battering ram useless.
Wrecked Battering Ram
Broken in various places, this wagon has seen better days.
A small flock of butterflies have gathered here, fluttering delicately with the breeze.
The wood's rich grain adds an unexpected vibrancy to this humble cabinet. Whoever crafted it clearly did so with great love.
The smell of woodsmoke draws you closer to the dancing fire. The sap of a birch log burns blue at its center.
A thick stew cooks over the fire. It smells bland, though, and ill-prepared.
Something roasts over the crackling fire. Grease drippings feed the flames below.
Thick tallow candles burn low upon their iron stand. Small mounds have formed on the floor below, where the fallen tallow has accumulated.
The catapult is small but well-built. With a proper counterweight, it should be able to deliver its payload quite a ways.
This catapult appears to have collapsed where it stood, perhaps by retreating forces who didn't want it turned against them.
Wrecked Catapult
It is a simple chair but the grace of its lines speaks to the quality of its craftmanship.
Bound in iron and with a heavy lock, this heavy chest was obviously meant to protect something of value.
Strange runes and pictographs, likely arcane in nature, have been scorched into the sides of this hide-covered strongbox.
Metal studs poke through the woodwork of this ornate chest. Judging by the fine craftsmanship, this strongbox appears to have been intended for public display.
Low and flat, this chest seems to have been designed for the storage and filing of a merchant's accounts.
The antique drawer pulls are touched by rust and the drawers themselves fit ill within their sockets. It seems the damp air has not been kind to this piece.
With its bucket head and straw-filled chest, the combat dummy seems far from threatening.
Either he owned little to begin with or this man was stripped of all he had.
Corpse
Rats nibble on the corpse's fingers and scurry about his ears. It looks like the body has been here awhile.
In death, the face of the bare-chested man seems frozen with fear. You wonder what it was that killed him.
The rickety cot seems well-used. The loose-woven cotton holds the shape of unknown bodies.
Cot
The sofa seems warm and inviting, perfect for a short nap.
A small drawer extends beneath the gleaming tabletop. It probably doubles as a desk when there's the need.
The marble is smooth and cool to the touch. You find it hard to determine where the stone ends and the water begins.
The smoke has an acrid smell, as if something foul smoulders at its source.
The old wagon lies empty, abandoned, like a faithful pet that still expects its master to come home.
Wagon
A tarp covers the wagon's cargo, possibly cabbages being brought to market.
Corpse Wagon
Fenberry Bush
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
Banner
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.

A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
A banner - stitched and dyed - denoting a point of interest.
The fire crackles and burns, consuming everything within its scorching heat.
Flame
The fire burns strong, fanned anew with each gust of air.
The fire is small and slow-burning. It leaves behind a small scattering of ash.
A complex series of runes that look as if they may mean something to a wizard. Perhaps only to the wizard that made them in the first place, though.
Floor Design
A swirl of a vortex adorns the floor. Its meaning is not known to you.
This symbol seems to point the way. But for good or not, you do not know.
A slender lever rises from the floor, controlling some unseen mechanism below.
Floor Lever
A heavy lever protrudes out of the ground, controlling some unseen mechanism below.
The chains on these floor-bound shackles are chipped and marked as if someone had been pounding on them with a rock. Whoever it was, it doesn't appear that their efforts met with any success.
Floor-anchored shackles
The low footstool is bound in an exotic leather, possibly monstrous in its origin.
Hearty bellows fan the forge-borne flames. The air is blisteringly hot, leaving you feeling light-headed and not quite yourself.
The water tumbles into the pool below, the sound of its fall marking a cheerful note.
Flies buzz around the fetid corpse. The body is curled into a fetal position as if cold or in great pain.
Plague Victim Corpse
The torch paints its environs in warmer hues. You find yourself grateful for its glow.
Torch Bracket
Crates of goods rest easy in the wagon, dusty from their recent journey.
Scraps and detritus cling together in an unsightly pile.
The sound of the machine is truly infernal, as if devils and demons made war against each other within.
Gnomish Contraption
If you listen closely, you can hear the brass gong resonating softly with your every step, as if acknowledging your presence.
A tuft of grass extends above the others, catching your eye.
Grass Tuft
The noose sways gently in the wind, as if searching for a corpse.
Gallows
The hay smells fresh and sweet, the product of some farmwife's labor.
Hay Bale
This granite headstone was carefully chiseled.
The sun-bleached corpse groans and shifts, a gust of wind giving it the brief appearance of unlife.
Impaled Human Corpse
Impaled Monster Corpse
This once-noble face now wears the gruesome mask of death. The eye sockets are bloodied and empty -- the ravens have already plucked the nectar out.
Impaled Human Head
Impaled Monster Head
You look about you, suspicious, but see nothing.
You can almost taste the hearty mead within the cask. It looks to have aged well.
The lamp post is pitted and scarred by the harsh night air.
This lectern is well-designed to hide the knocking knees of those who speak from it.
The sack seems small and poorly-sewn.
The sack seems plump and full.
The little sack is made of fine-spun cotton, tightly stitched.
The heavy sack dances with the sound of coins.
The satchel lies half-open, as if abandoned in the very act of being filled.
The satchel-clasp is hooked and drawn to ensure its contents don't spill out.
Blue sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Magic Sparks
Cyan-colored sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Green sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Orange sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Purple sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Blood-red sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Sparks, white and pure, rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
Golden sparks rise up from the ground like will-o'-wisps on cool night air.
The low pedestal gleams an alabaster white, shadows playing across its fluted column.
Pile of Stones
The dark stone of the pillar is inlaid with bands of gold.
Pillar
The rough-hewn beam shows the stains of countless sweaty hands and shoulders leaning up against it.
You can see the shapes of shellfish trapped within the limestone.

A tarp extends to protect this pile of bloated corpses from the sun.
A button protrudes from the wooden pillar.
A button protrudes from the limestone pillar.
A slender lever extends from the wooden pillar.
A slender lever extends from the limestone pillar.
An empty canvas sits upon the easel, ready for the painter's brush.
Easel
The plant seems cramped within its rootbound pot.
The small pressure plate appears to activate some hidden mechanism below.
Pressure Plate
The chain disappears into some unseen recess above you where it presumably activates some hidden mechanism.
Pull Chain
A small pile of rubble lays strewn about the ground.
The sacks exude a musty smell, like flour slowly rotting in the damp.
Sacks of Flour
Sarcophagus
An indecipherable message is scrawled on the tombside in fresh blood. You wonder what undead lord calls this sarcophagus his home.
The stone lid is heavy, designed as much to keep thieves out as to keep the dead entombed within.
Original bark still clings to the simple sawhorse, giving it a rustic charm.
You spy the soft leaves of a fenberry bush.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A carefully constructed marker denoting a point of interest.
A searing shaft of blue light descends from some unseen place above.
Shaft of Light
A searing shaft of cyan light descends from some unseen place above.
A searing shaft of green light descends from some unseen place above.
A searing shaft of orange light descends from some unseen place above.
A searing shaft of purple light descends from some unseen place above.
Shaft of Light
A searing shaft of red light descends from some unseen place above.
A searing shaft of white light descends from some unseen place above.
A searing shaft of golden light descends from some unseen place above.
A matted mass of webbing surrounds the central core of the cocoon.
Cocoon
It's hard to tell if the spears killed him or if his enemies pierced the corpse as a means of defilement.
Speared Corpse
The unblinking eyes of this stature blankly return your gaze. There is no marker identifying who this figure might have been.
The crumbled statue still bears the shadow of its former dignity.
Defaced Statue
The stocks lie open, the smell of rotten vegetables and human waste still clinging to it.
A few small stones are gathered here, their dull surfaces washed clean.
One leg seems slightly loose. You wonder how long the stool will last.
The sun gleams off the radiant dial, the shadow cast marking the time.
The rustic table is filled with knife marks, faded charcoal etchings, and the stains of spilt food.
The high-backed throne looms out of the shadows, drawing your attention. Something in the design of it fills your heart with dread.
Throne
Whether by magic or the weight of history, the gold-seated throne exudes confidence and authority. Wise are the rulers who have called this seat their own.
A simple mat adorns the floor, faded and worn with use.
The metal structure still seems to resonate with the screams of those held captive here.
Blood runs in rivulets from the well-pierced corpse, leaving stains upon the floor below.
Birds play in the branches above you, chirping merrily.
The leaves of this tree are slowly turning to gold as Autumn continues.
The sound of your footsteps echoes back to you, resonating from the urn's dark depths.
The wheel rests there with nowhere to go and no means to get there.
You can hear the steady drip of water. Reaching out your hand, you catch a drop within your palm.
The water trough is empty, the water having left nothing but its stain upon the wood.
The weapons lean into the wooden rack, waiting for release.
A smudge of dirt or ash marks the ground here.
Scorch Mark
The light penetrates only so far into the gloomy depths. From somewhere deep below, you hear something splash.
The smells of hickory smoke and fresh bread waft out of the earthen oven, making your mouth water.
Oven
Ants march along the small stack of firewood, claiming it as their own.

_Base
I need some spellcasting equipment.
Me need some spell-stuff now, please.
What kind of guild is this?
Me not know what guild is. You tell?
I've never told you my name before.
Me not tell name. How you know?
I must be on my way.
Me go back to adventure-stuff now. Bye.
I would like to join the guild.
Me like to would join your guild.
Evaluate me for guild membership.
Me do something to be guild member. You judge me.
Okay, bye.
Have you special equipment available for guild members?
Yes.
No.
Here is my 200 gold. Let me take the test again.
You take gold. Me try again.
Farewell, then.
Maybe you gots special stuff for guild members?
Well, hello, <FullName>. I had heard there was a new magic adept in service to the city. The guild of the Many-Starred Cloak welcomes you.
Well, if *that's* the greatest of your curiosities, then this is going to be an interesting conversation - of that I am certain!
I should think it would be obvious. Within this tower is stored Neverwinter's collected experience with the art and discipline of magic.
We are the Many-Starred Cloak, and it is our goal to bring each student of magic to the heights of their potential.
We provide access to our magical inventories, as well as free passage throughout the Cloaktower. Would you care to become a part of our guild?
Well, far be it from me to keep you from your duties. Visit again when you have need of us. Farewell.
Hmm... I recognize you. You are one of the new recruits under Aribeth, are you not? I'm sorry, <FullName>, but this is the spellcasters' guild. It will not interest you.
Well, I'm glad to hear that. But before you can join the guild, you have to be able to show competence in several important areas of ability.
For your first test, I need you to demonstrate to me that you can find knowledge on your own, and then apply it for unrelated requests.
To help you out, I will tell you where to start. Find me the following four items, and once you have done so, bring them to me.
Hello, <FirstName>. Are we back to continue on with our next round of challenges? Or did we have something else in mind?
The items may be found in the arcane laboratories of the Many-Starred Cloak, located throughout the city. The buildings are marked with sundials.
The four items that you must find are: a bit of clay, a flask of water, a puff of fog, and a bit of kindling wood. Mark well the order.
Welcome, member. What do you require?
You were sent for four reagents, and you do not have them. Return when you do.
You were sent for four reagents and you have them. Well done. Now you shall face a test of mind and body.
You have not yet destroyed the golem in my second challenge.
You will be teleported to a room where you must destroy one of my automatons. Tools will be found there that will simplify the task.
Then return when you are.
Then step into the portal and the test will begin.
Congratulations. You have shown great ingenuity. By destroying my automaton you have earned a place in the Many-Starred Cloak.
You have tried to destroy the automaton and have failed. There is a penalty for failure, but it is more a token gesture of your intent to continue.
If you wish to take the test again, the penalty will lighten your purse. A 200 gold piece "donation" to the guild will do.
Use the knowledge from my first task and this test will be simple, but if you leave before the automaton is destroyed, you have failed. Are you ready?
You may take animal companions or henchmen, but you are being tested, not they. If they cause you to fail, it is still your failure. Keep them under complete control.
Take this key. Beware, as the laboratories are guarded against would-be initiates. Return to me when you have the four items.
I present you with the symbol of your guild. Wear this cloak with pride, and know that the guild stands ready to serve in future.
The four items that you must find are: a bit of clay, a flask of water, a puff of fog, and a bit of kindling wood. Mark well the order.
Good day, I wish you well.
Keep movin', you're blocking my view.
Looks like trouble - I'm sounding the alarm!
I'll keep an eye on the door.
Heh, nothing. Just looking at the architecture.
All right, but I'll deal with you later.
How dare you - Draw steel!
By Lord Nasher and Lady Aribeth, grant me entrance.
Me want in.
Oh, me just looking at all da pretty bricks...
Dat's it! No more dumb jokes! Me flatten your head!
Ooh, me deal wit' you later...
Scram? Ooh, dat's it! Me flatten your head!
I'm on the other side of a stout door, nitwit.
What do you want, lap dog?
Move along, then, and keep that tail between your legs where it belongs.
Sorry, no flatheads on the guest list. Next.
Your precious lords and ladies mean nothing in these parts... Scram, you hear me?
What do you want, pretty thing?
Yeah? What do you want?
Life must be an endless marvel for folks like you...
The prison, eh? How do I get there?
I'm sure the prisoners are safely locked away.
Don't worry, ma'am. I'll look into it.

Bah! I'm in this for the gold. You can all rot.

City safe. Prisoners all in prison, right?
Why me care about this stuff?

Bah! Me look for gold. You can all rot.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Me good guy. It okay to talk.
What are you doing in my home? Oh, as if there isn't enough trouble around here.
Who are you? I hope you are a guard. We need more around here. There's trouble in the prison, and nobody's doing much about it.
Just wind your way up to the top o' the Peninsula. The guards walk that path twice a day, though I suppose it's a fair bit more dangerous now.
If only they were! They prowl the streets with the gall to say... oh nothing! I don't know who to trust these days...
It ain't my business if you do or don't. I'd think, though, that if you've the power to help, you've a duty to do it.
May the Wailing catch you, then. I won't share the same air you breathe.
It's good there are still decent folk about in these times. Best of luck to you, then.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Oh very well. The prisoners who escaped are saying that it was the Head Gaoler himself who set them loose...
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> I have to keep my mouth shut, <sir/madam>. My life might be on the line. Please, just leave me alone.
You would think that. Commander Alaefin is the Head Gaoler there. He's always been so kind to us... He was a good man once.
Oh nothing. I don't know who to trust these days...
Well, I don't want to confuse you. Just keep going up. You get to the top of the Peninsula, you'll be there. I imagine it's pretty dangerous right now, though.
Yes, please give me Helm's blessing.
No thanks, but have you any other services?
No thanks. Carry on with your work.
Could you answer some questions for me?
Have you any other services?
Thank you, that will be all.
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Tell me about Desther, your superior.

May Helm watch and bless you in this time of suffering.
You there, shall I bless you with this living water, once cupped within the Guardian's palm? It keeps the plague at bay, at least for a while.
May this child of the mortal realm be blessed, touched by the comforting waters that Desther has blessed in the name of Helm. Let the eye watch over your fate.
Go with comfort. I wish you well in the dark times ahead.
What would you care to know?
Watchknight Desther is a holy man, to be sure. He was appointed to watch over Neverwinter at Shieldmeet. A grand honor.
We all journeyed with him from Helm's Hold and arrived here scant days after Lady Aribeth declared the quarantine.
Yes... the holy symbol of Helm. Well, obviously it is an open gauntlet, which symbolizes the... the peace brought by having an armored protector. We are guardians.
And in the center of the palm is the eye. Eyes are very important. They see all, know all, speak to us. They watch and learn. Yes.
It is a horrible plague, grave in its implications and beyond the reach of any normal cure.
Yet the faithful pass unscathed - no Helmite suffers from its boils... we pass unfettered to administer our blessings of comfort.
I have temple services, if you require.
Yes, Helm protects the simple, too.
Yes, Helm protects the simple, too.
Yes, Helm protects the simple, too.
Yes, Helm protects the simple, too.
Noble one, shall I anoint you with this living water, once cupped within the Guardian's palm? It keeps the plague at bay, at least for a while.
You, with the... rough exterior, shall I cleanse you with this living water, once cupped within the Guardian's palm? It keeps the plague at bay, at least for a while.
The militia have kept me safe enough. I must say, though, that it's served as quite the distraction from any quest for a cure, don't you think?
In the end, it seems one of the Waterdhavian creatures was behind it all. The guards are cleaning up the last pockets of resistance now...
Any good stores in the district?
Where can I find some healing around here?
That will be all, Gate Captain.
Me sell stuff here, right?
You heal me, yuh?
Me go, okay?
How did they escape?
Where's this prison?
Are any areas still safe?
Does the militia have a plan of attack?
Thanks for the warning.
How dey get out?
Where dis prison?
It still safe some places, yuh?
What da militia plannin'?
Okay, me go now den.
Look, people feel uncomfortable enough just living around that prison, let alone tossing their money around near it. This place is a shopkeeper's nightmare, all right?
One of those new Helmites was performing his blessings somewhere to the southwest before all hell broke loose. Maybe he's still there now.
All right, then. Stay out of trouble.
You're a few wheels short of a wagon, aren't you...
Do I look like a Storekeep to you? I'm not: I'm a Gate Guard.
Don't go far - we need to talk, citizen.
If you're going onto the Peninsula, keep your head up. There's been a prison break and the place is crawling with trouble.
Rumor is that Captain Alaefin, the Head Gaoler, set them free. Makes no sense to me - he was a good man and ran a tight ship...
Southwest of here, at the top of the hill. It commands a great view of the harbor... not that the prisoners ever got to see it.
Sedos Sebile is the one in charge of the operation. The prisoners have her pretty much penned-in, but she's managed to secure a headquarters to the southeast.
If you're looking to help, I'd recommend you go see her. She has better information on what's going on than I do.
For now everyone's just trying to figure out what's going on. Someone's going to have to go into that prison though, and get to the bottom of it.
If you want to thank me, go talk to Sedos Sebile at headquarters. We could definitely use your help cleaning up the Head Gaoler's mess...
Phew, it's been a hell of a day. I'm just glad the prison break's been handled and dealt with.

I will not be usssed in your spellssss. Your plague isss nothing to me!

I can't say much. I live and work in the City Core. The Blacklake district is beyond my means, and I certainly have no business in the others.
I don't bother with the Beggar's Nest, the Docks, or the Peninsula. They were rough enough before the Wailing took hold.
Sorry, I really don't get out of the City Core much. Especially now with the plague everywhere. It's just not safe.
That is where you are now. It is the business center of the city. Really, this should all be evident to you after just walking around.
Home to the slums. The Beggar's Nest was poor enough before the Wailing. I don't want to think about what it would be like now.
Good. I don't need strange people invading my home.

I can't tell you anything about the place. I've been lucky enough to save a few coins here and there.
I don't know much about it. I try to stay away from the rougher areas of the city. I hear talk about pirates, but I wouldn't know.
The Blacklake district is the wealthiest part of the city. I don't have much cause to go there. I can't afford to look like I belong there.
I've got no reason to know anything about the Peninsula district. Only the roughest of our criminal element end up there.
It's worse than the Docks, I hear. I've never been there, though.
Which district did you want to ask about? I don't know much.
I don't pay much attention to politics. I follow Lord Nasher as our leader, and Lady Aribeth of the Neverwinter Nine.
Lord Nasher has pledged any needed resources to curing the plague. He has been quite supportive, as any leader would when tragedy strikes.

Now, are we just about done? You are still in my home uninvited.
I don't know any specifics, but she has been on the front lines of everything, working with people, trying to organize.

Maybe tell about other city places?
Greetings in these dark days. Is there aught than I can offer one as esteemed as yourself?
Yes? Is there something you require? These dark days have left my mind on other things so make it brief.
I've no desire to speak with someone as rough-hewn as you, least of all in times such as these. Leave me be.
You are in need of more than that, by the sound of you. I will endeavor to speak slowly.
I can spare a few moments from my worrying. What is it that you wish to know?
It has cost me my business, for one. I was visiting friends in the City Core when the quarantine came down. My store is now empty and forgotten beyond those gates.
I have trusted associates that say a cure was being assembled, but something apparently disrupted the attempt. An attack, they say.
My business and I have ended up on separate sides of the quarantine, I'm afraid. I cannot guess what has become of my dockhands now.
That is a tenuous link, and as much of one as I would want. Still, I suppose it is true enough. What harm can come of it?
This information has wisely been kept from the masses. Can you imagine the panic? Actually, I probably shouldn't have even told *you*.
It is ripe with the Wailing and I suspect that is where the plague first manifested. Hardly a surprise with all the filth that make their homes there.
It *kills* us! In the Wailing's eyes, we are no better than the lowliest of peasants. Where is the privilege of class now, I ask...
Hopefully we will do more than just let the Wailing take us. The actions of Lord Nasher and the Helmites have been underwhelming.
If you wish to know more of the matter, you should go to the district yourself. Trapped on this side of the quarantine, I am hardly current on such matters.
I understand there was trouble there recently. Someone has put an end to it, however, and nothing of interest about the place comes to mind.
A revolt? Why should the nobles revolt when they already hold the power! I merely suggested that provisions are being made for certain citizens of Blacklake to survive the plague.
Goodbye. Perhaps we'll both live to talk another time...
I am to be your simple guide? Hmph... Though if it would help toward a cure, I suppose I should endeavor to answer.
The different districts will each hold intrigues, I am sure. All but the Blacklake seem to do as they will when out from under the rule of law.
Very well, if this dreaded Wailing makes me serve as your signpost... Neverwinter is divided into five districts, each encompassing a particular industrious theme.
Which would you have questions about? The Beggar's Nest, the Docks, the Blacklake district, the Peninsula, or the City Core?
I don't sully myself by discussing mere conjecture. If you wish salacious details I suggest you look elsewhere.
The irony is not lost on me - I could have shown you to my own stock, once, and made a tidy profit from you, too... Instead, I point you to other establishments...
You look a bit of a scoundrel. You may want to visit the Moonstone Mask, near the Peninsula Gate in the City Core west.
You look the type to be concerned with the interests of nature. Perhaps you should visit the Druid Tree on the east side of the City Core's upper square.
Are you a pious individual? Perhaps you would benefit from visiting the Temple of Tyr in the City Core on the west side of the City Core's upper square.
Are you of an arcane bent? You might wish to make yourself known at the Cloaktower, just outside Castle Never.
You look handy with a weapon. You might wish to visit Shining Knight Arms and Armor in the southeast City Core.
... Not that someone of my stature would know anything of such a place - I merely mention it as a courtesy.
If you are looking for manpower, however, you may wish to visit the Trade of Blades mercenary enclave in the southwest.
The City Core, my captain of redundancy, is where we now stand. Basic services are here, as well as specialized training.
Castle Never in the northeast is the city's heart. The "upper square" around it contains important spiritual and cultural institutions.
I know little of the Beggar's Nest, but that's hardly a failing. Only the poor and morally suspect willingly visit such a place.
I don't concern myself with the Docks. I have subordinates to handle the day-to-day workings of business and shipping... at least, I used to...
Ahh, only the best of us make our homes in the Blacklake district. It was the most privileged of the districts until it, too, fell within the Wailing's grasp.
Not even the status of residents could prevent the encroachement of the plague, though I hear some have... Ah, but I should speak no more of this.
Bah! What should I know of the Peninsula? It's a haven for those either caged in the prison or recently released from it.
The district edge, however, is possessed of more suspect establishments... for the most part, however, the militia's quarantine has kept us free of the Wailing.
That district is held to the thinnest thread of law by Captain Alaefin, the Head Gaoler. I have seen little of him since the cursed Wailing came.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> You know, you're right. A dullard such as yourself will forget what I say with the next shiny thing that captures your attention.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I find your manner quite disarming. I suppose I could reveal one or two points. You may find them of interest.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> No, I rather think not. Blacklake district will handle its own affairs, thank you.
It's rather exciting, though dangerous as well. I hope the common people will understand that the ruling class knows best.
I really shouldn't give away any more. Suffice to say that certain nobles of Blacklake are making certain they survive this mess.
Could I trouble you with some questions?
Me wants to ask questions from you.
Goodbye.
Me want to know about different city areas.
Can you tell me anything about the plague?
I require some information about locations in Neverwinter.
Is there anything odd that you have heard?
You knows much about the plague?
Me wants to have information about Neverwinter places.
Maybe yous heard some rumors or something?
What do you know about cure attempts?
You know about cure attempts maybe?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Has the plague disrupted the social order of the city?
I want to ask something else.
Me ask different questions.
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> Are you suggesting a revolt of some sort?
What are the different areas of the city?
Tell me about the Beggar's Nest.
Tell me about the Docks district.
Tell me about the Blacklake district.
Tell me about the Peninsula.
Where can I get equipment?
Where me get equipment?
Tell me about the City Core.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> Certainly you can tell me.
<StartCheck>[Persuade]</Start> You can tell me. Why worries about me?
Certainly you can tell me? We are <race> kin.
We both <race> kind. Why not tell me?
You tells about City Core.
You tells about Beggar's Nest.
You tells about the Docks district.
You tells about the Blacklake.
You tells about Peninsula.
I need to ask about other city districts.
Me ask about other areas?
Well hello there. You seem to be of noble blood, like me. We must stick together in these horrible times, don't you think, my fine-mannered friend?
Yes? Is there something you require? Please do be brief as your unwashed appearance leaves me to worry what infections you might be carrying...
Can you not see that I am in the midst of mourning? Show some respect for your betters, both living and dead!
I will comply, though it appears I will have to eschew my natural preference for proper grammar.
I suppose one still needs to breathe amidst one's mourning - Perhaps in helping you I am also helping my friends' spirits find their rest.
I have lost my two closest friends to it already. The Helmites say they must be cremated rather than buried - but they did the Blacklake proud, at least...
The great unwashed have been kept ignorant of bungled efforts by city officials to contain the disease, and for good reason.
I even heard the area has fallen under the control of gangs of thugs and pirates, though whether this is true or simply an exaggeration I couldn't say.
I may share the race of your birth, but we are worlds apart. Still, these troubled times make strange allies of us all.
Components for a cure were lost to an attack. Can you imagine the panic if people knew that someone is actually fighting against the cure?
I hear it is now infested with zombies of the plague-dead - It serves the lower classes right for cursing us with such a dreadful pox!
Disrupted? The privileged do not take well to change - Why, captains of commerce are falling just as quick as their menial workers.
It won't be tolerated. The inaction of Lord Nasher and those under him will not hinder the nobilty from protecting their own.
If you have an opinion on the matter you should go to the district yourself and leave me to mourn the sacrifice.
I understand there was trouble there recently but someone has put an end to it. Even so, the guards will not allow me to attend my friends' funerals.
My friends would have nothing to do with something so barbaric! It was simply a matter of the proper precautions being taken.
Fare thee well. I must return to my private mourning - It is the only way I have to grieve.
I don't usually have much regard for those that lose their way, but... well, the Wailing changes everything, doesn't it...
The different districts will each hold intrigues, I am sure. All but the Blacklake seem to do as they will once out from under the rule of law.
Neverwinter has always been divided into separate Districts but, with the militia maintaining the quarantine at every gate, it has become all the more apparent.
Which of the five is of interest to you? The Beggar's Nest, the Docks, the Blacklake district, the Peninsula, or the City Core?
The gossip of the nobility need not concern you, and likely wouldn't be the type of information you want anyway.
If you'll be using that equipment to avenge my friends or bring about a cure for us all, I'll gladly point you in the right direction.
I get the sense, however, that you seek something larcenous in nature. I'd suggest visiting the Moonstone Mask, near the Peninsula exit in the City Core west.
You seem to move by Nature's hand? Perhaps the Druid Tree in the City Core upper square east would be a location of interest for you.
You appear quite strong in your faith. Perhaps you should pay a visit to the Temple of Tyr in the City Core upper square west.
Are scrolls and incantations your interest? You might wish to make yourself known at the Cloaktower, just outside Castle Never.
You look quick with a weapon. The Shining Knight Arms and Armor in the southeast City Core may have what you are looking for.
Not that I have ever been there, and any assumption that I have is merely the wildest of conjecture.
Ah, and If you wish to bolster yourself with a hireling, the Trade of Blades mercenary enclave in the southwest is where the adventurers are gathering.
The City Core is where we are now and is one of the only districts where the plague has not made much headway.
Our more important institutions are located around Castle Never in the "upper square," the center of Neverwinter's government.
The Beggar's Nest is where the Wailing first laid its claim upon the city and it remains the worst afflicted... Not that it had been pleasant before.
A friend of mine, a warehouser, says business is at a standstill there - The Wailing has left idle hands about, leading to mischief among the laborers.
The Blacklake district - My friends lived and now have died there... The militia won't let me attend the funeral, though they said they'd pass on my regards.
But beyond my personal affection for my home, the Blacklake is where the best hope of beating the plague will arise... but that is not for your ears.
I have little interest in the Peninsula district's affairs. There is already too much to worry about without fretting over the inmates of its prison.
The edge of this district is full of rough-hewn establishments that, while they offer more variety, the quality of their goods and services is more often suspect.
Now there are even rumors of prisoners running free in the streets - You are better off leaving it alone.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Well, I suppose I could say a little. It's not as though you will fully understand, anyway.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I suppose I could mention a detail or two. It's not as though it hasn't been bandied about among my circle.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> No, I rather think not. Blacklake district will handle its own affairs, thank you.
You see, Blacklake will not fall to the plague quietly. There have been measures taken, stockpiling and... certain acquisitions...
I can't say much more, but my friends have not died in vain. They exposed themselves to the plague that other nobles in the Blacklake might survive.
Of course, I have heard nothing of suspects or leads. What are we coming to if the nobility cannot expect to be kept updated?
I need to ask a few questions.
You can answer questions, yuh?
Goodbye.
Me want to know about different city areas.
What do you know of the plague?
I need infomation about places in Neverwinter.
Have you heard of anything odd? Any rumors?
You know anything about the bad plague?
Me wants information about places in Neverwinter.
Maybe you hear about odd stuff or rumors?

You know about cure attempts maybe?
<StartCheck>[Insight]</Start> You sound like you don't particularly like Aribeth.

Me ask about other city places.
What were you told about the Waterdhavian creatues?
What you told about Water-doozian things?
Good morrow to you, citizen. Wait... are you a new recruit? Aye, they're replacing the ones we've lost, are they?
Can I help you? I cannot be away from my duty for long. Wait... are you a new recruit? Aye, they're replacing the ones we've lost...
You have my attention. Wait, you're one of the patchwork recruits, aren't you? Ahh, you're no substitute for experience.
Well I'll try to speak slowly for you. I've seen smarter recruits, that's for sure - that said, the dumb aren't always the first to die...
Hmm, the more information you have, the less risk you'll pose to the rest of us on duty. I'll help if I can.
I know what I'm told. Aribeth and her lot handle all the delicate stuff. We common guards keep the peace where we can and maintain the quarantine at all costs.
Not a thing. I was briefed on the Waterdhavian creatures, but nothing since. My life's on the line to keep the streets clear of rioters and looters.
The Wailing's brought out the worst in them. There's a panic for gold for some reason. Not sure why. The rich die too.
Anyway, not much happening in there now, though I'm still losing men to the Wailing. We'll keep an eye on it though.
There's been word of a prison riot, though. Tyr only knows we've never been able to instill fear in the inmates but maybe the Wailing finally has...
It's where the plague first appeared. The first few cases were ignored as a "problem with the poor" but now there's something else...
She handles city security on a big scale, reporting to Lord Nasher. She brings in people like you for special missions, leaving us for little things like, oh, restraining plague-maddened rioters.
Pardon me if I don't think she's more important than the dozens of us who have already been put to the torch thanks to the Wailing's touch!
We're scared, all right? You should be too! You want to throw yourself at whatever is in there, you go ahead. Good on you.
In fact, I think they were talking revolt for a while, but somebody put a stop to it. Was that you? My thanks go out to you if it was.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> Look, I'm here to do my job and let you do yours.
Stay alive out there, recruit.
Well, you can't keep the peace without knowing where to keep it, can you? Sorry, it's an old guard joke my buddy used to tell before... nevermind.
With us gone, the different districts each hold their intrigues, I'm sure. All I know is that we're fighting a losing battle, even here in the Core...
The city's always had Districts, but with the quarantine we've been ordered to lock things down. As a result, each District has ended up handling things differently.
Which do you have questions about? There's the Beggar's Nest, the Docks, the Blacklake district, the Peninsula, and the City Core? You need to know them all.
All I hear is how bad things are getting, how many more men we've lost. It's like a war, except you can't make the Wailing surrender.
There are several merchants in the City Core, but some are raising prices like there's no tomorrow. Of course, they might be right...
Make sure I don't catch you around the Moonstone Mask. It's in the west near the Peninsula exit. You kind of look the type...
You need nature-related supplies, don't you? You look the type. You should visit the Druid Tree in the City Core upper square east.
You look... I don't know, devout, I guess. You might want to check out the Temple of Tyr in the City Core upper square west.
You're a spell-tosser, aren't you? The Cloaktower is just outside Castle Never, and might have what you need.
You good with a weapon? Shining Knight Arms and Armor has the best gear - I shop there myself. They're in the southeast City Core.
They cater to the shady and the flamboyant. I suppose they do stock the odd thing that can't be had elsewhere... not legally, anyway.
And if you want someone to back you up, check the Trade of Blades mercenary enclave in the southwest. Good people there.
The City Core is the business center, and is built around Castle Never. We've been able to keep it largely free of the Wailing but not entirely...
It's also where we keep the tightest rule of law. This is true normally, but even more so now with the plague causing havoc.
The Beggar's Nest is hurting bad. There's a lot of poverty - I've already lost three of my men to violence there and another eight to Wailing.
The Docks are a nightmare to patrol even at the best of times. There's dirty gold there. Not a lot of respect for the city guards.
Blacklake? Bunch of spoiled nobles. I don't think they've had a good word for the guards in the history of the city. And there's those rumors...
People are saying the nobles stumbled on a cure and they won't share it with the rest of us. Probably not true, but it would be just like them.
The Peninsula holds the prison. There's a good number of staff that live in the area, as well as people on their way out.
Of course, with most of what remains of the militia here, the other Districts are suffering. Hopefully that's where you can help.
Captain Alaefin runs the place and I hope he's doing okay because he's one of the best the city has to offer...
Things went a little nuts for a while, but it's settling down. Maybe you had a hand in that. Good for you if you did.
You want to go poke your nose around... whatever's in the Beggar's Nest, you go right ahead. Make yourself a hero.
There's not much we can do. Muggers and bands of thugs have the run of the place now. I guess they won the war...
Nobody cared about the Beggar's Nest before and it's not vital we save it now. Just remember that I've lost better men than you in there.
Look, this isn't what the guards signed on for. We keep the peace. We don't know anything about plague or... what come after.
Things are looking up, though. Somebody restored a semblance of order - Destroyed a whole infestation of undead. It sure makes our job a lot easier.
Maybe you had something to do with that? If so, thanks. It's been pretty quiet in there ever since.
People are barricading wherever they can, and there are even rumors of undead walking the streets. I'm afraid there's not much the guards can do to help.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Look, the guards are hired to keep the peace and maintain the quarantine. We're hunters of the living, not the dead.
I even heard something about them openly threatening some of my guards. If they don't fall in line, the whole place is going to hell.
I do know that those damned Helmites keep getting in our way, though. I swear, their blessings better do HALF of what they say.
I'm not sure what all happened in there, but it seems to have calmed down now. Hell of a price to pay, though.
Captain Alaefin was a good man and my thanks go out to whoever put him out of his misery. The riots have finally calmed down, though.
That the caravan bringing them was attacked when it entered the city. Nobody knows what happened to them after that - scattered to the wind, I guess.
Well, nobody except you, maybe. I've heard that you've been making great strides finding them. Good on you. Better than most have done.
The cure attempt they were for is still up in the air, I guess. They don't tell me about details. They just said keep an eye out for them.
I want to ask you some questions.
Me want some informations.
Goodbye.

I need to ask about the other districts.
Me ask about other city areas.
There's no replacement for family but you look like a friendly face...
What is it you need, then? I have worries of my own, you know...
Why my children, huh? Why couldn't the Wailing have taken someone like you, instead?
You want some informations? All right, dunce, all you have to do is ask.
I can spare a few moments. Perhaps the idle chatter will clear my thoughts.
I know I don't want to get it. The Wailing took my entire family, one after the other. I watched 'em die, every one - They shriveled up from the inside.
Bah, won't tell us "simple people." They think we'd panic if there was no hope or stampede if a cure was announced.
Last little while I've heard the place is almost overrun with thieves, too. People seem to really need gold for something.
I suppose we are both <race>. Ah, all right. I don't know much anyway, so I'm in the clear.
I ain't heard a single thing, and I probably won't. I'm not sure whether it's a blessing or a curse but I'm alive...
And don't think it's coincidence that the plague seemed to start in the Beggar's Nest, either! The rich needed an excuse to clear it out.
Would I know the difference? It's just that the eyes go dead long before a person stops moving... That's when the Wailing starts...
Maybe those Helmites are right. Maybe it's a wasting of the soul. Maybe the gods are mad at us... My question is how come I survived?
Maybe you heard about that, or maybe you had a part in it? I dunno, but the area seems much more calm... aside from the Wailing, of course.
I even heard they were trying to hoard food and part of a cure! Someone put a stop to it though.
I hear things are getting better though. There was some infighting or something, but now it's been settled. Less muggings too.
Thanks for the distraction from my troubles - I hope your kin don't fall prey the same as mine...
Neverwinter... This city was a good place once. Now it's nothing but burning bodies piled in the streets. I don't even have a family anymore.
You want to go poking around for stories, go right ahead. I'm going to stay right here: in the street and out of trouble.
It's set out like an eye - the City Core, where we are now, is the pupil. Around it lie the other districts... Through it all runs the river, all fed by tears.
Do you want to hear about the Beggar's Nest? The Docks? The Blacklake? The Peninsula? The City Core? Take your pick - I have a lifetime, however short.
As if I care about anything else right now. I'm scared to go home, to see the bodies. I'm scared maybe I'll catch it too.
That would depend on what you are looking for. I suppose I could make my best guess at what you want.
You work a bit outside the law, maybe? Don't worry, my lips are sealed. I know somewhere that might interest you, though...
You one of them nature-talking forest-walkers, aren't you? I suppose you might visit the Druid Tree in the City Core upper square east.
You looking for a temple or something? You'll find what you want at the Temple of Tyr in the City Core upper square west.
You a spellcaster or something? There's lots of that sort of thing at the Cloaktower, just outside Castle Never.
You need a good blade or something? Shining Knight Arms and Armor in the southeast City Core has the best.
The Moonstone Mask near the Peninsula exit in the City Core west - They have all sorts of interesting things there.
And if you want a sucker to absorb damage for ya, visit the Trade of Blades mercenary enclave in the southwest.
That's where we is now. Got all your basic services as such. Lots of different kinds of people make their home here... Less every day, mind you...
Castle Never is in the northeast - That's the upper square where all the "informed elite" do their business.
Beggar's Nest? Don't let anyone sour you on that place - Good honest poor people live and die there. Not like Blacklake or the Docks.
I used to do the occasional odd job in Docks district, but not any more. Didn't like working for pirates.
Bah! Bunch of stuck up nobles. The Wailing has them tied in knots - Kills them just the same as any commoner, and that fact drives 'em nuts.
Apparently they're even seizing resources meant for us poorer folk. My brother wouldn't have passed away so easy if he only had a little food in him.
You really don't know the city if you have to ask. Nobody wants to go to the Peninsula. That's where the prison is.
Myself, I usually find what I need around the outer edge. Of course, stock is down all over because of the Wailing.
The prison is usually run pretty strict, but I don't want to imagine what the plague has done to it.
Maybe that was you? Well, I'm glad they got shook up. They deserved it and it quieted things down out there, too.
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> I'm not actually a part of it, so I guess I'm in the clear. Not that I know all that much.
Stay clear of the Docks. Losing your family is worry enough without losing your purse, too. The guards are no help neither.
See, the Blacklake nobles, and I don't know exactly who, are hoarding food. It's made them a lot of enemies.
Last I heard there was rioting because of them. Don't know how it turned out. Not my business. Being the last left of my family, I've got other worries.
Things are a lot better, too. The Wailing's still rough, but someone cleared out some zombies or something that were causing trouble.
I hope none of them zombies were my family - Though if they were, I'd like to thank whoever did the clearing for giving them their due rest...
<StartCheck>[Success]</Start> Ah, you won't understand anything anyway so I guess it's okay to tell you.
<StartCheck>[Failure]</Start> It's not for me to say. I'm not involved and I don't know much, anyway. Being the last left of my family, I've got other worries.
It's settled down a bit now. I guess there was some killings, and even the captain of the place died.
Not my business, but I'm glad they sorted it out. You have something to do with that? Good on you if you did.
I even heard -but I ain't saying from who- that some prisoners and guards have been killed. Wonder what's going on in there...
Now there's even some zombies or something... I hope none of them are my family - I wouldn't want them to have to be like that.
